	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">European Union</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"EU" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/EU_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="EU (disambiguation)">EU (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Economic and political union of European states</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>

in Europe">Christian</a></li><li><div class="plainlist" style="font-size:90%;margin-left:1em"><ul><li>45.3% <a href="/wiki/Catholicism_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism in  </li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="14" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/46px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1000" /></span> <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a>
 </li><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></span> <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;b&#93;</a></sup>
 </li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_European_Union" title="Politics of the European Union">Government</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/Supranational_union" title="Supranational union">Supranational</a> and <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmentalism" title="Intergovernmentalism">intergovernmental</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the Council</a> </div></th><td><a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Parliament" title="President of the European Parliament">President of the Parliament</a> </div></th><td><a href="/wiki/David_Sassoli" title="David Sassoli">David Sassoli</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the Commission</a> </div></th><td><a href="/wiki/Jean-Claude_Juncker" title="Jean-Claude Juncker">Jean-Claude Juncker</a></td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr><th scope="row">Legislature</th><td><i>see <a href="#Politics">"Politics" section</a> below</i></td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_European_Union" title="History of the European Union">Formation</a><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a> </div></th><td>1 January 1958</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Single_European_Act" title="Single European Act">Single European Act</a> </div></th><td>1 July 1987</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Treaty of Maastricht</a></span> </div></th><td>1 November 1993</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> </div></th><td>1 December 2009</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/2013_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2013 enlargement of the European Union">Last polity admitted</a> </div></th><td>1 July 2013</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_European_Union" title="Geography of the European Union">Area </a></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Total</div></th><td>4,475,757&#160;km<sup>2</sup> <div class="NavHead" style="font-size: 105%; background:transparent;text-align:left;font-weight:normal;">10 others</div>

</div></td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th scope="row">Time zone</th><td><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>&#160;to&#160;UTC+2</span> (<a href="/wiki/Western_European_Time" title="Western European Time">WET</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Time" title="Central European Time">CET</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_European_Time" title="Eastern European Time">EET</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;Summer&#160;(<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)</div></th><td><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+1&#160;to&#160;UTC+3</span> (<a href="/wiki/Western_European_Summer_Time" title="Western European Summer notation in Europe">Date and time notation in Europe</a></i></span></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">.eu</a><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;e&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><div style="line-height:11pt"><b>Website</b><br /><span class="url"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://europa.eu/">europa<wbr />.eu</a></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>European Union</b> (<b>EU</b>) is a political and economic union of <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">28 member states</a> that are located primarily in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> Its members have a combined area of 4,475,757&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (1,728,099&#160;sq&#160;mi) and an estimated total population of about 513 million. The EU has developed <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">an internal single market</a> through a standardised <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">system of laws</a> that apply in all member states in those matters, and only those matters, where members have agreed to act as one. EU policies aim to ensure the free movement of people, goods, services and capital within the internal market,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Internal_Market_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Internal_Market-18">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> enact legislation in justice and home affairs and maintain common policies on trade,<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Common_Fisheries_Policy" title="Common Fisheries Policy">fisheries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regional_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Regional policy of the European Union">regional development</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> For travel within the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>, passport controls have been abolished.<sup id="cite_ref-Internal_borders_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Internal_borders-22">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">A monetary union</a> was established in 1999 and came into full force in 2002 and is composed of <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">19 EU member states</a> which use the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro currency</a>.
</p><p>The EU and <a href="/wiki/European_citizenship" class="mw-redirect" title="European citizenship">European citizenship</a> were established when the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> came into force in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115-23">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> The EU traces its origins to the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a> (ECSC) and the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC), established, respectively, by the 1951 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1951)" title="Treaty of Paris (1951)">Treaty of Paris</a> and 1957 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a>. The original members of what came to be known as the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> were the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Six" title="Inner Six">Inner Six</a>: Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a>. The Communities and their successors have grown in size by <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">the accession of new member states</a> and in power by the addition of policy areas to their remit. The latest major amendment to the constitutional basis of the EU, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>, came into force in 2009. No member state has <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_from_the_European_Union" title="Withdrawal from the European Union">left the EU</a> or its antecedent organisations (<a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>, an autonomous territory within <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>, left the Communities in 1985). However, the United Kingdom <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_invocation_of_Article_50_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union" title="United Kingdom invocation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union">signified its intention to leave</a> after a <a href="/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum">membership referendum</a> in June 2016 and is <a href="/wiki/Brexit_negotiations" title="Brexit negotiations">negotiating its withdrawal</a>.
</p><p>Containing 7.3% of the world population,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> the EU in 2017 generated a nominal <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) of 19.670 trillion US dollars, constituting approximately 24.6% of global <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Additionally, all 28 EU countries have a very high <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, according to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Program" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Development Program">United Nations Development Programme</a>. In 2012, the EU was awarded the <a href="/wiki/2012_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2012 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> Through the <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a>, the EU has developed a role in <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_European_Union" title="Foreign relations of the European Union">external relations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Military of the European Union">defence</a>. The union maintains permanent <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_European_Union" title="List of diplomatic missions of the European Union">diplomatic missions</a> throughout the world and <a href="/wiki/European_Union_and_the_United_Nations" title="European Union and the United Nations">represents itself</a> at the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_and_the_G7" title="European Union and the G7">G7</a> and the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>. Because of its global influence, the European Union was described in 2006 as an <a href="/wiki/European_Union_as_an_emerging_superpower" title="European Union as an emerging superpower">emerging superpower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_European_Superpower_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_European_Superpower-27">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_European_Union" title="History of the European Union">History of the European Union</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Europe" title="History of Europe">History of Europe</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ideas_of_European_unity_before_1945" title="Ideas of European unity before 1945">Ideas of European unity before 1945</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:IE_expansion.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/IE_expansion.png/220px-IE_expansion.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/IE_expansion.png/330px-IE_expansion.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/IE_expansion.png/440px-IE_expansion.png 2x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="275" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:IE_expansion.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Scheme of <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European migrations</a> from c. 4000 to 1000 BCE according to the <a href="/wiki/Kurgan_hypothesis" title="Kurgan hypothesis">Kurgan hypothesis</a> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid Magenta; background-color:Magenta; color:black; font-size:60%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;The assumed <i><a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_Urheimat_hypotheses" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Indo-European Urheimat hypotheses">Urheimat</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Samara_culture" title="Samara culture">Samara culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sredny_Stog_culture" title="Sredny Stog culture">Sredny Stog culture</a>) and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Yamnaya_culture" title="Yamnaya culture">Yamnaya culture</a>.</div> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid Red; background-color:Red; color:black; font-size:60%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Area possibly settled up to c. 2500 BCE.</div> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid Coral; background-color:Coral; color:black; font-size:60%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Area settled up to 1000 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> </div></div></div></div> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_814.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Europe_814.svg/220px-Europe_814.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Europe_814.svg/330px-Europe_814.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Europe_814.svg/440px-Europe_814.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1399" data-file-height="919" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_814.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">Early Middle Ages</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png/220px-Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png/330px-Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png/440px-Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png 2x" data-file-width="2534" data-file-height="1540" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Roman_Empire_Trajan_117AD.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Roman Empire in AD 117, at its greatest extent (with its <a href="/wiki/Vassal_state" title="Vassal state">vassals</a> in pink).</div></div></div>
<p>During the centuries following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">fall of Rome</a> in 476, several European States viewed themselves as <i><a href="/wiki/Translatio_imperii" title="Translatio imperii">translatio imperii</a></i> ("transfer of rule") of the defunct <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankish Empire">Frankish Empire</a> (481–843) and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a> (962–1806) were thereby attempts to resurrect <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Rome in the West</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;f&#93;</a></sup> This political philosophy of a supra-national rule over the continent, similar to the example of the ancient Roman Empire, resulted in the early Middle Ages in the concept of a <i>renovatio imperii</i> ("restoration of the empire"),<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> either in the forms of the <i>Reichsidee</i> ("imperial idea") or the religiously inspired <i>Imperium Christianum</i> ("christian empire").<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup> Medieval <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> and the political power of the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Papacy</a><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> are often cited as conducive to European integration and unity.
</p><p>In the oriental parts of the continent, the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Russian Tsardom</a>, and ultimately the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Empire</a> (1547–1917), declared Moscow to be <a href="/wiki/Third_Rome#Russian_claims" title="Third Rome">Third Rome</a> and inheritor of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Eastern tradition</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a> in 1453.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> The gap between <a href="/wiki/Greek_East_and_Latin_West" title="Greek East and Latin West">Greek East and Latin West</a> had already been widened by the political scission&#160;of the Roman Empire in the 4th century and the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism of 1054</a>; and would be eventually widened again by the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Curtain" title="Iron Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> (1945–91).<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>
Pan-European political thought truly emerged during the 19th century, inspired by the liberal ideas of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French</a> and <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolutions</a> after the demise of <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">Napoléon's Empire</a> (1804–15). In the decades following the outcomes of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>, ideals of European unity flourished across the continent, especially in the writings of <a href="/wiki/Wojciech_Jastrz%C4%99bowski" title="Wojciech Jastrzębowski">Wojciech Jastrzębowski</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Mazzini" title="Giuseppe Mazzini">Giuseppe Mazzini</a><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Theodore_de_Korwin_Szymanowski" title="Theodore de Korwin Szymanowski">Theodore de Korwin Szymanowski</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> The term <i><a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Europe" title="United States of Europe">United States of Europe</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>: <i lang="fr">États-Unis d'Europe</i>) was used at that time by <a href="/wiki/Victor_Hugo" title="Victor Hugo">Victor Hugo</a> during a speech at the <a href="/wiki/International_Peace_Congress" title="International Peace Congress">International Peace Congress</a> held in Paris in 1849:<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CongressVienna.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/CongressVienna.jpg/220px-CongressVienna.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/CongressVienna.jpg/330px-CongressVienna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/CongressVienna.jpg/440px-CongressVienna.jpg 2x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="305" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:CongressVienna.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Congress_of_Vienna" class="mw-redirect" title="The Congress of Vienna">The Congress of Vienna</a> met in 1814–15. The objective of the Congress was to settle the many issues arising from the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, and the dissolution of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>.</div></div></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>A day will come when all nations on our continent will form a European brotherhood ... A day will come when we shall see ... the United States of America and the United States of Europe face to face, reaching out for each other across the seas.
</p></blockquote><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Interwar_period" title="Interwar period">interwar period</a>, the consciousness that national markets in Europe were interdependent though confrontational, along with the observation of a larger and growing US market on the other side of the ocean, nourished the urge for the economic integration of the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> In 1920, advocating the creation of a <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European economic union</a>, British economist <a href="/wiki/John_Maynard_Keynes" title="John Maynard Keynes">John Maynard Keynes</a> wrote that "a Free Trade Union should be established ... to impose no protectionist tariffs whatever against the produce of other members of the Union."<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> During the same decade, <a href="/wiki/Richard_von_Coudenhove-Kalergi" title="Richard von Coudenhove-Kalergi">Richard von Coudenhove-Kalergi</a>, one of the first to imagine of a modern political union of Europe, founded the <a href="/wiki/Paneuropean_Union" title="Paneuropean Union">Pan-Europa Movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> His ideas influenced his contemporaries, among which then <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France" title="Prime Minister of France">Prime Minister of France</a> <a href="/wiki/Aristide_Briand" title="Aristide Briand">Aristide Briand</a>. In 1929, the latter gave a speech in favour of a European Union before the assembly of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a>, precursor of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> In a <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ibiblio.org/pha/policy/1943/1943-03-21a.html">radio address</a> in March 1943, with war still raging, Britain's leader Sir <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://winstonchurchill.org/resources/speeches/1941-1945-war-leader/national-address/">spoke</a> warmly of "restoring the true greatness of Europe" once victory had been achieved, and mused on the post-war creation of a "Council of Europe" which would bring the European nations together to build peace.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup>
</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht,_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg/220px-Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg/330px-Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg/440px-Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht%2C_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3397" data-file-height="2854" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_Congres_Ridderzaal_Den_Haag._Overzicht,_Bestanddeelnr_902-7379.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Meeting in the <a href="/wiki/Ridderzaal" title="Ridderzaal">Hall of Knights</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">The Hague</a>, during the congress (May 9, 1948)</div></div></div>
<h3><span id="Preliminary_.281945.E2.80.9357.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Preliminary_(1945–57)">Preliminary (1945–57)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><div id="mwe_player_1" class="PopUpMediaTransform" style="width:220px;" videopayload="&lt;div class=&quot;mediaContainer&quot; style=&quot;width:384px&quot;&gt;&lt;video id=&quot;mwe_player_2&quot; poster=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg/384px--Schuman_Declaration.ogg.jpg&quot; controls=&quot;&quot; preload=&quot;none&quot; autoplay=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;width:384px;height:288px&quot; class=&quot;kskin&quot; data-durationhint=&quot;27.92&quot; data-startoffset=&quot;0&quot; data-mwtitle=&quot;Schuman_Declaration.ogg&quot; data-mwprovider=&quot;local&quot;&gt;&lt;source src=&quot;//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg&quot; type=&quot;video/ogg; codecs=&amp;quot;theora, vorbis&amp;quot;&quot; data-title=&quot;Original Ogg file, 384 × 288 (588 kbps)&quot; data-shorttitle=&quot;Ogg source&quot; data-width=&quot;384&quot; data-height=&quot;288&quot; data-bandwidth=&quot;587607&quot; data-framerate=&quot;25&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=bg&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;bg&quot; label=&quot;български (bg) subtitles&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=en&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;en&quot; label=&quot;English (en) subtitles&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;track src=&quot;/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;amp;title=File%3ASchuman_Declaration.ogg&amp;amp;lang=eu&amp;amp;trackformat=srt&quot; kind=&quot;subtitles&quot; type=&quot;text/x-srt&quot; srclang=&quot;eu&quot; label=&quot;euskara (eu) subtitles&quot; data-dir=&quot;ltr&quot;/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;"><img alt="File:Schuman Declaration.ogg" style="width:220px;height:165px" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg/220px-seek%3D23-Schuman_Declaration.ogg.jpg" /><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/00/Schuman_Declaration.ogg" title="Play media" target="new"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a></div>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Schuman_Declaration.ogg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Robert_Schuman" title="Robert Schuman">Robert Schuman</a> <a href="/wiki/Schuman_Declaration" title="Schuman Declaration">proposing</a> the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">Coal and Steel Community</a> on <a href="/wiki/Europe_Day" title="Europe Day">9 May</a> 1950</div></div></div>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a> was seen as an antidote to the extreme nationalism which had devastated the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> In a speech delivered on 19 September 1946 at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Z%C3%BCrich" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Zürich">University of Zürich</a>, Switzerland, <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> went further and advocated the emergence of a <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Europe" title="United States of Europe">United States of Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> The 1948 <a href="/wiki/Hague_Congress_(1948)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hague Congress (1948)">Hague Congress</a> was a pivotal moment in European federal history, as it led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/European_Movement_International" title="European Movement International">European Movement International</a> and of the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Europe" title="College of Europe">College of Europe</a>, where Europe's future leaders would live and study together.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>It also led directly to the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> in 1949, the first great effort to bring the nations of Europe together, initially ten of them. However, the Council focused primarily on values—human rights and democracy—rather than on economic or trade issues, and was always envisaged as a forum where sovereign governments could choose to work together, with no supra-national authority. It raised great hopes of further European integration, and there were fevered debates in the two years that followed as to how this could be achieved.
</p><p>But in 1952, disappointed at what they saw as the lack of progress within the Council of Europe, six nations decided to go further and created the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a>, which was declared to be "a first step in the federation of Europe".<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> This community helped to economically integrate and coordinate the large number of <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> funds from the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> European leaders <a href="/wiki/Alcide_De_Gasperi" title="Alcide De Gasperi">Alcide De Gasperi</a> from Italy, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Monnet" title="Jean Monnet">Jean Monnet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Schuman" title="Robert Schuman">Robert Schuman</a> from France, and <a href="/wiki/Paul-Henri_Spaak" title="Paul-Henri Spaak">Paul-Henri Spaak</a> from Belgium understood that coal and steel were the two industries essential for waging war, and believed that by tying their national industries together, future war between their nations became much less likely.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_45-59_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_45-59-54">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> These men and others are officially credited as the <a href="/wiki/Founding_fathers_of_the_European_Union" title="Founding fathers of the European Union">founding fathers of the European Union</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Treaty_of_Rome_.281957.E2.80.9392.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Treaty_of_Rome_(1957–92)">Treaty of Rome (1957–92)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif/280px-EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif" decoding="async" width="280" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif/420px-EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif/560px-EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="520" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EC-EU-enlargement_animation.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The continental territories of the member states of the European Union (European Communities pre-1993), coloured in order of accession</div></div></div>
<p>In 1957, Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and West Germany signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a>, which created the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC) and established a <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">customs union</a>. They also signed another pact creating the <a href="/wiki/European_Atomic_Energy_Community" title="European Atomic Energy Community">European Atomic Energy Community</a> (Euratom) for co-operation in developing <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear energy</a>. Both treaties came into force in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_45-59_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_45-59-54">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The EEC and Euratom were created separately from the ECSC, although they shared the same courts and the Common Assembly. The EEC was headed by <a href="/wiki/Walter_Hallstein" title="Walter Hallstein">Walter Hallstein</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hallstein_Commission" title="Hallstein Commission">Hallstein Commission</a>) and Euratom was headed by <a href="/wiki/Louis_Armand" title="Louis Armand">Louis Armand</a> (<a href="/wiki/Armand_Commission" title="Armand Commission">Armand Commission</a>) and then <a href="/wiki/%C3%89tienne_Hirsch" title="Étienne Hirsch">Étienne Hirsch</a>. Euratom was to integrate sectors in nuclear energy while the EEC would develop a customs union among members.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1960s, tensions began to show, with France seeking to limit supranational power. Nevertheless, in 1965 an agreement was reached and on 1 July 1967 the <a href="/wiki/Merger_Treaty" title="Merger Treaty">Merger Treaty</a> created a single set of institutions for the three communities, which were collectively referred to as the <i><a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_Merge_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_Merge-57">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jean_Rey_(politician)" title="Jean Rey (politician)">Jean Rey</a> <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">presided over</a> the first merged Commission (<a href="/wiki/Rey_Commission" title="Rey Commission">Rey Commission</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg/220px-West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg/330px-West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg/440px-West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg 2x" data-file-width="661" data-file-height="498" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1989, the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Curtain" title="Iron Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> fell, enabling the Community to <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">expand</a> further (<a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a> pictured)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1973, the Communities were enlarged to include <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>, which later <a href="/wiki/1982_Greenlandic_European_Communities_membership_referendum" title="1982 Greenlandic European Communities membership referendum">left the Communities</a> in 1985, following a dispute over fishing rights), <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_the_United_Kingdom_to_the_European_Communities" title="Accession of the United Kingdom to the European Communities">United Kingdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_First_enlargement_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_First_enlargement-60">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> Norway had negotiated to join at the same time, but Norwegian voters rejected membership in a <a href="/wiki/1972_Norwegian_European_Communities_membership_referendum" title="1972 Norwegian European Communities membership referendum">referendum</a>. In 1979, the <a href="/wiki/1979_European_Parliament_election" title="1979 European Parliament election">first direct elections</a> to the European Parliament were held.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_New_Parliament_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_New_Parliament-61">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> joined in 1981, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> following in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-ENA_Enlargement_negotiations_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENA_Enlargement_negotiations-62">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> In 1985, the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a> paved the way for the creation of open borders without passport controls between most member states and some non-member states.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> In 1986, the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe">European flag</a> began to be used by the EEC<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Single_European_Act" title="Single European Act">Single European Act</a> was signed.
</p><p>In 1990, after <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">the fall of the Eastern Bloc</a>, the former <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a> became part of the Communities as part of a <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">reunified Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_80-89_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_80-89-65">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> A close fiscal integration with the introduction of the euro was not matched by institutional oversight making things more troubling.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (October 2018)">when?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Attempts to solve the problems and to make the EU<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (October 2018)">when?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> more efficient and coherent had limited success.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-66">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Maastricht_Treaty_.281992.E2.80.932007.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Maastricht_Treaty_(1992–2007)">Maastricht Treaty (1992–2007)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Euro_banknotes_2002.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Euro_banknotes_2002.png/220px-Euro_banknotes_2002.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Euro_banknotes_2002.png/330px-Euro_banknotes_2002.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Euro_banknotes_2002.png/440px-Euro_banknotes_2002.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="587" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Euro_banknotes_2002.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> was introduced in 2002, replacing 12 national currencies. Seven countries have since joined.</div></div></div>
<p>The European Union was formally established when the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>—whose main architects were <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Kohl" title="Helmut Kohl">Helmut Kohl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Mitterrand" title="François Mitterrand">François Mitterrand</a>—came into force on 1 November 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraigDe_Burca201115-23">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> The treaty also gave the name <a href="/wiki/European_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="European Community">European Community</a> to the EEC, even if it was referred as such before the treaty. With further enlargement planned to include the former <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist states</a> of Central and Eastern Europe, as well as <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_criteria" title="Copenhagen criteria">Copenhagen criteria</a> for candidate members to join the EU were agreed upon in June 1993. The expansion of the EU introduced a new level of complexity and discord.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-66">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> In 1995, <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> joined the EU.
</p><p>In 2002, euro banknotes and coins replaced national currencies in 12 of the member states. Since then, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> has increased to encompass 19 countries. The euro currency became the second largest reserve currency in the world. In 2004, the EU saw <a href="/wiki/2004_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="2004 enlargement of the European Union">its biggest enlargement to date</a> when <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> joined the Union.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_00_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_00-68">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Lisbon_Treaty_.282007.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Lisbon_Treaty_(2007–present)">Lisbon Treaty (2007–present)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="521" data-file-height="310" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> entered into force in 2009</div></div></div>
<p>In 2007, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> became EU members. The same year, <a href="/wiki/Slovenian_euro_coins" title="Slovenian euro coins">Slovenia</a> adopted the euro,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_History_00_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_History_00-68">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> followed in 2008 by <a href="/wiki/Cypriot_euro_coins" title="Cypriot euro coins">Cyprus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maltese_euro_coins" title="Maltese euro coins">Malta</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Slovak_euro_coins" title="Slovak euro coins">Slovakia</a> in 2009, by <a href="/wiki/Estonian_euro_coins" title="Estonian euro coins">Estonia</a> in 2011, by <a href="/wiki/Latvian_euro_coins" title="Latvian euro coins">Latvia</a> in 2014, and by <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_euro_coins" class="mw-redirect" title="Lithuania euro coins">Lithuania</a> in 2015.
</p><p>On 1 December 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> entered into force and reformed many aspects of the EU. In particular, it changed the legal structure of the European Union, merging the <a href="/wiki/Three_pillars_of_the_European_Union" title="Three pillars of the European Union">EU three pillars</a> system into a single legal entity provisioned with a <a href="/wiki/Legal_personality" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal personality">legal personality</a>, created a permanent <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a>, the first of which was <a href="/wiki/Herman_Van_Rompuy" title="Herman Van Rompuy">Herman Van Rompuy</a>, and strengthened the position of the <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPiris2010448_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPiris2010448-69">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg/220px-Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg/330px-Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg/440px-Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Rome_anniversary_group_photograph_2017-03-25_03.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Group photograph of European Union heads of government on occasion of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome</a> in Rome, Italy</div></div></div>
<p>In 2012, the EU received the <a href="/wiki/2012_Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="2012 Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> for having "contributed to the advancement of peace and reconciliation, democracy, and human rights in Europe."<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> In 2013, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a> became the 28th EU member.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>From the beginning of the 2010s, the cohesion of the European Union has been tested by several issues, including <a href="/wiki/European_debt_crisis" title="European debt crisis">a debt crisis in some of the Eurozone countries</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis" title="European migrant crisis">increasing migration from the Middle East</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">United Kingdom's withdrawal from the EU</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCUKREFRESLT_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCUKREFRESLT-74">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum">referendum in the UK on its membership of the European Union</a> was held in 2016, with 51.9% of participants voting to leave.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTEUBrexit_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTEUBrexit-75">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> The UK formally notified the European Council of its decision to leave on 29 March 2017, initiating the <a href="/wiki/Article_50_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union">formal withdrawal procedure for leaving the EU</a>, committing the UK in principle to leave the EU two years later, on 29 March 2019,<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> unless an extension was sought and granted, which occurred.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Structural_evolution">Structural evolution</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">Treaties of the European Union</a></div>
<p>The following timeline illustrates the <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">integration</a> that has led to the formation of the present union, in terms of structural development driven by international treaties:
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_enlargement">Future enlargement</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Future_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Future enlargement of the European Union">Future enlargement of the European Union</a></div>
<p>The criteria for accession to the Union are included in the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_criteria" title="Copenhagen criteria">Copenhagen criteria</a>, agreed in 1993, and the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Maastricht treaty">Treaty of Maastricht</a> (Article 49). Article 49 of the Maastricht Treaty (as amended) says that any "European state" that respects the "principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, and the rule of law", may apply to join the EU.  Whether a country is European or not is subject to <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_criteria#Geographic_criteria" title="Copenhagen criteria">political assessment</a> by the EU institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-briefing23_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-briefing23-77">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There are five recognised candidates for future <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">membership</a> of the Union: <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">Turkey</a> (applied on 14 April 1987), <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_North_Macedonia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of North Macedonia to the European Union">North Macedonia</a> (applied on 22 March 2004 as "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia"), <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Montenegro_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Montenegro to the European Union">Montenegro</a> (applied in 2008), <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Albania_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Albania to the European Union">Albania</a> (applied in 2009), and <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Serbia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Serbia to the European Union">Serbia</a> (applied in 2009). While the others are progressing, Turkish talks are at an effective standstill.<sup id="cite_ref-Hahn_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hahn-78">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_European_Union" title="Demographics of the European Union">Demographics of the European Union</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Population">Population</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg/200px-Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="197" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg/300px-Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg/400px-Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="609" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Density_of_Population_in_EU_2014.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>EU population density in 2014</div></div></div>
<p>As of 1&#160;January&#160;2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Union&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the population of the European Union was about 513.5&#160;million people (6.9% of the world population).<sup id="cite_ref-population_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-population-9">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup> In 2015, 5.1 million children were born in the EU-28, corresponding to a <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> of 10 per 1,000, which is 8 births below the world average.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> For comparison, the EU-28 birth rate had stood at 10.6 in 2000, 12.8 in 1985 and 16.3 in 1970.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth</a> rate was positive at an estimated 0.23% in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010, 47.3 million people who lived in the EU were born outside their resident country. This corresponds to 9.4% of the total EU population. Of these, 31.4 million (6.3%) were born outside the EU and 16.0 million (3.2%) were born in another EU member state. The largest absolute numbers of people born outside the EU were in Germany (6.4 million), France (5.1 million), the United Kingdom (4.7 million), Spain (4.1 million), Italy (3.2 million), and the Netherlands (1.4 million).<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> In 2017, approximately 825,000 persons acquired <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">citizenship</a> of a member state of the European Union. The <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Europe" title="Immigration to Europe">largest groups</a> were nationals of Morocco, Albania, India, Turkey and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> 2.4 million <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Europe" title="Immigration to Europe">immigrants</a> from non-EU countries entered the EU in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_European_Union_by_population_within_city_limits" title="List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits">List of cities in the European Union by population within city limits</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_European_Union" title="List of urban areas in the European Union">list of urban areas in the European Union</a></div>
<p>The EU contains about 40 urban areas with populations of over one million, including the two&#160;<a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacities</a>&#160;(cities with a population of over 10 million) of <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat-89">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Also, there are several other metropolises with a population of over 5 million like <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> and includes polycentric urbanised regions like <a href="/wiki/Rhine-Ruhr" title="Rhine-Ruhr">Rhine-Ruhr</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cologne" title="Cologne">Cologne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dortmund" title="Dortmund">Dortmund</a>, <a href="/wiki/D%C3%BCsseldorf" title="Düsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a> et al.), <a href="/wiki/Randstad" title="Randstad">Randstad</a> (<a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rotterdam" title="Rotterdam">Rotterdam</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">The Hague</a>, <a href="/wiki/Utrecht" title="Utrecht">Utrecht</a> et al.), <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Rhine-Main" title="Frankfurt Rhine-Main">Frankfurt Rhine-Main</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Flemish_Diamond" title="Flemish Diamond">Flemish Diamond</a> (<a href="/wiki/Antwerp" title="Antwerp">Antwerp</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leuven" title="Leuven">Leuven</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghent" title="Ghent">Ghent</a> et al.) and <a href="/wiki/Upper_Silesian_metropolitan_area" title="Upper Silesian metropolitan area">Upper Silesian area</a> (<a href="/wiki/Katowice" title="Katowice">Katowice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ostrava" title="Ostrava">Ostrava</a> et al.).<sup id="cite_ref-eurostat_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eurostat-89">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<table class="navbox" style="width: 100%">

<p><br />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">Languages of the European Union</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Euro_English" title="Euro English">Euro English</a></div>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>
</td>
<td>&lt;1%
</td>
<td>&lt;1%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a>
</td>
<td>&lt;1%
</td>
<td>&lt;1%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>
</td>
<td>&lt;1%
</td>
<td>&lt;1%
</td></tr>
<tr class="sortbottom">
<td colspan="3" style="text-align:left;">
<p><small>Survey 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup><br />
Native: Native language<sup id="cite_ref-nativeLanguages_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nativeLanguages-92">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup><br />
Total: EU citizens able to hold a<br />conversation in this language<sup id="cite_ref-totalLanguages_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-totalLanguages-93">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup></small>
</p>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The European Union has 24 official languages: <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">Dutch</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finnish_language" title="Finnish language">Finnish</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">Romanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Swedish_language" title="Swedish language">Swedish</a>. Important documents, such as legislation, are translated into every official language and the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> provides translation for documents and plenary sessions.<sup id="cite_ref-Official_Languages_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Official_Languages-94">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Due to the high number of official idioms, most of the institutions use only a handful of working languages.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> The European Commission conducts its internal business in three <i>procedural languages</i>: English, French, and German. Similarly, the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">European Court of Justice</a> uses French as the working language,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> conducts its business primarily in English.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Even though <a href="/wiki/Language_policy" title="Language policy">language policy</a> is the responsibility of member states, EU institutions promote multilingualism among its citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;g&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> English is the most widely spoken language in the EU, being understood by 51% of the EU population when counting both native and non-native speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurobarometer_Languages_P4_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurobarometer_Languages_P4-104">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> German is the most widely spoken mother tongue (16% of the EU population). More than half (56%) of EU citizens are able to engage in a conversation in a language other than their mother tongue.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurobarometer_Languages_P3_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurobarometer_Languages_P3-105">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Most official languages of the EU belong to the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a> <a href="/wiki/Language_family" title="Language family">language family</a>, represented by the <a href="/wiki/Balto-Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Balto-Slavic">Balto-Slavic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;h&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Italic_languages" title="Italic languages">Italic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;i&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Germanic Europe">Germanic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;j&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_languages" title="Hellenic languages">Hellenic</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;k&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic</a><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;l&#93;</a></sup> branches. Some EU languages, however, namely <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finnish_language" title="Finnish language">Finnish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a> (all three <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic</a>), <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;m&#93;</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Language_isolate" title="Language isolate">isolate</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a> (<a href="/wiki/Semitic_languages" title="Semitic languages">Semitic</a>), do not belong to Indo-European languages.<sup id="cite_ref-Many_tongues,_one_family_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Many_tongues,_one_family-112">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> The three official alphabets of the European Union (<a href="/wiki/Cyrillic_script" title="Cyrillic script">Cyrillic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greek_alphabet" title="Greek alphabet">modern Greek</a>) all derive from the <a href="/wiki/Archaic_Greek_alphabets" title="Archaic Greek alphabets">Archaic Greek scripts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-4">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Besides the 24 official languages, there are about 150 <a href="/wiki/Regional_language" title="Regional language">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">minority languages</a>, spoken by up to 50&#160;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-Many_tongues,_one_family_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Many_tongues,_one_family-112">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">Galician</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a> are not recognised official languages of the European Union but have semi-official status: official translations of the treaties are made into them and citizens have the right to correspond with the institutions in these languages.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-114">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a> ratified by most EU states provides general guidelines that states can follow to protect their linguistic heritage. The <a href="/wiki/European_Day_of_Languages" title="European Day of Languages">European Day of Languages</a> is held annually on 26 September and is aimed at encouraging language learning across Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_European_Union" title="Religion in the European Union">Religion in the European Union</a></div>
<table class="wikitable sortable floatleft" style="font-size: 90%">
<caption style="font-size:100%">Religious affiliation in the European Union (2015)<sup id="cite_ref-EB2015_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB2015-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</caption>
<tbody><tr>
<th>Affiliation
</th>
<th colspan="2">% of EU population
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a>
</td>
<td align="right">71.6
</td>
<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">71.6</span><div style="width:143.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:darkblue">&#160;</div>
</td></tr>

</td>

</td></tr>

<td style="text-indent:15px;">Other Christian
</td>
<td align="right">5.6
</td>

</td>

</td>

</td></tr>

</td>
<td align="right">24
</td>

</td></tr>
