</td>
<td align="right">13.6
</td>
<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">13.6</span><div style="width:27.2px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightgrey">&#160;</div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-indent:15px;"><a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">Atheist</a>
</td>
<td align="right">10.4
</td>
<td align="left"><span style="display:none;">10.4</span><div style="width:20.8px;height:2ex;background:#aaa;background:lightgrey">&#160;</div>
</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>The EU has no formal connection to any religion. The Article 17 of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> recognises the "status under national law of churches and religious associations" as well as that of "philosophical and non-confessional organisations".<sup id="cite_ref-Consolidated_Treaties_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Consolidated_Treaties-118">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The preamble to the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Treaty on European Union</a> mentions the "cultural, religious and humanist inheritance of Europe".<sup id="cite_ref-Consolidated_Treaties_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Consolidated_Treaties-118">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> Discussion over the draft texts of the European Constitution and later the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> included proposals to mention <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> or a <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">god</a>, or both, in the preamble of the text, but the idea faced opposition and was dropped.<sup id="cite_ref-EUO_Merkel_God_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUO_Merkel_God-119">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Christians in the European Union are divided among members of Catholicism (both <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Rite</a>), numerous <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> denominations (<a href="/wiki/Anglicans" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglicans">Anglicans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutherans" class="mw-redirect" title="Lutherans">Lutherans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reformed" class="mw-redirect" title="Reformed">Reformed</a> forming the bulk of this category), and the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>. In 2009, the EU had an estimated <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Muslim_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by Muslim population">Muslim population</a> of 13&#160;million,<sup id="cite_ref-mgmpPRC_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mgmpPRC-120">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> and an estimated <a href="/wiki/Jewish_population" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish population">Jewish population</a> of over a million.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> The other world religions of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> are also represented in the EU population.
</p><p>According to new polls about religiosity in the European Union in 2015 by <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">Eurobarometer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> is the largest religion in the European Union, accounting for 71.6% of the EU population. <a href="/wiki/Catholics" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholics">Catholics</a> are the largest Christian group, accounting for 45.3% of the EU population, while <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestants</a> make up 11.1%, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a> make up 9.6%, and other Christians make up 5.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-EB2015_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB2015-5">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Eurobarometer" title="Eurobarometer">Eurobarometer</a> opinion polls showed in 2005 that 52% of EU citizens believed in a god, 27% in "some sort of spirit or life force", and 18% had no form of belief.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Religion_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Religion-122">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> Many countries have experienced falling church attendance and membership in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-About_SecE_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-About_SecE-123">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> The countries where the fewest people reported a religious belief were Estonia (16%) and the Czech Republic (19%).<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Religion_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Religion-122">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> The most religious countries were Malta (95%, predominantly Roman Catholic) as well as Cyprus and Romania (both predominantly Orthodox) each with about 90% of citizens professing a belief in their respective god. Across the EU, belief was higher among women, older people, those with religious upbringing, those who left school at 15 or 16, and those "positioning themselves on the right of the political scale".<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat_Religion_122-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat_Religion-122">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Member_states">Member states</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">Member state of the European Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png/300px-EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png/450px-EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png/600px-EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png 2x" data-file-width="2206" data-file-height="1358" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_OCT_and_OMR_map_en.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>EU's member states and <a href="/wiki/Special_member_state_territories_and_the_European_Union" title="Special member state territories and the European Union">special territories of the European Union</a></div></div></div>
<p>Through successive <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">enlargements</a>, the European Union has grown from the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Six" title="Inner Six">six founding states</a> (Belgium, France, West Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands) to the current 28. Countries accede to the union by becoming party to the founding <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaties</a>, thereby subjecting themselves to the privileges and obligations of EU membership. This entails a partial delegation of sovereignty to the institutions in return for representation within those institutions, a practice often referred to as "pooling of sovereignty".<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>To become a member, a country must meet the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_criteria" title="Copenhagen criteria">Copenhagen criteria</a>, defined at the 1993 meeting of the European Council in Copenhagen. These require a stable democracy that respects human rights and the <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a>; a functioning <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>; and the acceptance of the obligations of membership, including EU law. Evaluation of a country's fulfilment of the criteria is the responsibility of the European Council.<sup id="cite_ref-Accession_Criteria_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Accession_Criteria-126">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> No member state has yet left the Union, although <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> (an <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous area">autonomous province</a> of Denmark) withdrew in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Article_50_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union">Article 50</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> provides the basis for a member to <a href="/wiki/Withdrawal_from_the_European_Union" title="Withdrawal from the European Union">leave the Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> Since mid-2017, the United Kingdom has been <a href="/wiki/Brexit_negotiations" title="Brexit negotiations">negotiating terms for its withdrawal</a> from the EU.
</p><p>There are six countries that are recognised as <a href="/wiki/Future_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Future enlargement of the European Union">candidates for membership</a>: <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Albania_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Albania to the European Union">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Iceland_to_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Accession of Iceland to the European Union">Iceland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_North_Macedonia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of North Macedonia to the European Union">North Macedonia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;n&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Montenegro_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Montenegro to the European Union">Montenegro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Serbia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Serbia to the European Union">Serbia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Turkey_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Turkey to the European Union">Turkey</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Enlargement_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Enlargement-130">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> though Iceland suspended negotiations in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-icelandover_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-icelandover-131">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Kosovo_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Kosovo to the European Union">Kosovo</a> are officially recognised as potential candidates,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Enlargement_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Enlargement-130">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> with Bosnia and Herzegovina having submitted a membership application.
</p><p>The four countries forming the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a> (EFTA) are not EU members, but have partly committed to the EU's economy and regulations: Iceland, <a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, which are a part of the <a href="/wiki/Single_market" title="Single market">single market</a> through the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, which has similar ties through <a href="/wiki/Switzerland%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="Switzerland–European Union relations">bilateral treaties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EEA_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EEA-132">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CH_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CH-133">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> The relationships of the <a href="/wiki/Microstates_and_the_European_Union" title="Microstates and the European Union">European microstates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">Andorra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a>, <a href="/wiki/San_Marino" title="San Marino">San Marino</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> include the use of the euro and other areas of co-operation.<sup id="cite_ref-euro_use_world_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euro_use_world-134">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> The following 28 <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign states</a> (of which the map only shows territories situated in and around Europe) constitute the European Union:<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_European_Union" title="Geography of the European Union">Geography of the European Union</a></div>
<p>The EU's member states cover an area of 4,423,147 square kilometres (1,707,787&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-Area.and.population.figure_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Area.and.population.figure-137">&#91;p&#93;</a></sup> The EU's highest peak is <a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Graian_Alps" title="Graian Alps">Graian Alps</a>, 4,810.45 metres (15,782&#160;ft) <a href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" class="mw-redirect" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> The lowest points in the EU are <a href="/wiki/Lammefjorden" title="Lammefjorden">Lammefjorden</a>, Denmark and <a href="/wiki/Zuidplaspolder" title="Zuidplaspolder">Zuidplaspolder</a>, Netherlands, at 7&#160;m (23&#160;ft) below sea level.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup>
The landscape, climate, and economy of the EU are influenced by its coastline, which is 65,993 kilometres (41,006&#160;mi) long.
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px"><div style="width: 182px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg/270px-Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg/405px-Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg/540px-Pe%C3%B1%C3%B3n_de_Ifach_-_Calpe-_Spain.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5184" data-file-height="3456" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>65,993&#160;km (41,006&#160;mi) coastline dominates the European climate (<a href="/wiki/Natural_Park_of_Penyal_d%27Ifac" title="Natural Park of Penyal d&#39;Ifac">Natural Park of Penyal d'Ifac</a>, Spain)
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162.66666666667px"><div style="width: 162.66666666667px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 160.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG/241px-Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG" decoding="async" width="161" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG/361px-Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG/481px-Mont-Blanc_and_Lake_of_Passy.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2288" data-file-height="1712" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Mont_Blanc" title="Mont Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a> is the highest peak in the EU
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 176.66666666667px"><div style="width: 176.66666666667px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 174.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg/262px-Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg/393px-Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg/524px-Parliament_Budapest_Hungary.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1163" data-file-height="800" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> (pictured in Budapest), is the longest river in the European Union
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 202px"><div style="width: 202px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 200px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/300px-Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/449px-Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg/599px-Repoveden_Kansallispuisto_Kesayonauringossa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="616" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Repovesi_National_Park" title="Repovesi National Park">Repovesi</a> National Park in Finland, where there are some 187,888 lakes larger than 500 square metres
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<p>Including the overseas territories of France which are located outside the continent of Europe, but which are members of the union, the EU experiences most <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">types of climate</a> from <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">Arctic</a> (north-east Europe) to tropical (<a href="/wiki/French_Guiana" title="French Guiana">French Guiana</a>), rendering meteorological averages for the EU as a whole meaningless. The majority of the population lives in areas with a temperate <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">maritime climate</a> (North-Western Europe and Central Europe), a <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (Southern Europe), or a warm summer continental or <a href="/wiki/Hemiboreal" title="Hemiboreal">hemiboreal</a> climate (Northern <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and Central Europe).<sup id="cite_ref-Humid_Continental_climate_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Humid_Continental_climate-140">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The EU's population is highly urbanised, with some 75% of inhabitants living in <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban areas</a> as of 2006. Cities are largely spread out across the EU, although with a <a href="/wiki/Blue_Banana" title="Blue Banana">large grouping</a> in and around the <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">Benelux</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_European_Union" title="Politics of the European Union">Politics of the European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Institutions_of_the_European_Union" title="Institutions of the European Union">Institutions of the European Union</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Legislature_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislature of the European Union">Legislature of the European Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg/400px-Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="283" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg/600px-Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg/800px-Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1052" data-file-height="744" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Organs_of_the_European_Union.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Organigram of the political system with the seven institutions of the Union in blue, national / intergovernmental elements in orange</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_(40894703423).jpg" class="image"><img alt="The candidates standing onstage" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_%2840894703423%29.jpg/220px-Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_%2840894703423%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_%2840894703423%29.jpg/330px-Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_%2840894703423%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_%2840894703423%29.jpg/440px-Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_%2840894703423%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2040" data-file-height="1358" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Debate_of_lead_candidates_for_the_European_Commission_presidency_(40894703423).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>European Commission presidency candidates at <i><a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Debate" title="Eurovision Debate">Eurovision Debate</a></i> (May 2019). Left to right: Zahradil, Cué, Keller, Vestager, Timmermans, Weber</div></div></div>
<p>The EU operates through a hybrid system of <a href="/wiki/Supranational_union" title="Supranational union">supranational</a> and <a href="/wiki/Intergovernmentalism" title="Intergovernmentalism">intergovernmental</a> decision-making,<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-142">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CIA_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-143">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> and according to the principles of <a href="/wiki/Principle_of_conferral" title="Principle of conferral">conferral</a> (which says that it should act only within the limits of the competences conferred on it by the <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaties</a>) and of <a href="/wiki/Subsidiarity#European_Union_law" title="Subsidiarity">subsidiarity</a> (which says that it should act only where an objective cannot be sufficiently achieved by the member states acting alone). <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">Laws made by the EU institutions</a> are passed in a variety of forms.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> Generally speaking, they can be classified into two groups: those which come into force without the necessity for national implementation measures (regulations) and those which specifically require national implementation measures (directives).<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Constitutionally, the EU bears some resemblance to both a <a href="/wiki/Confederation" title="Confederation">confederation</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup> but has not formally defined itself as either. (It does not have a formal constitution: its status is defined by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of European Union">Treaty of European Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>). It is more integrated than a traditional confederation of states because the general level of government widely employs <a href="/wiki/Qualified_majority_voting" class="mw-redirect" title="Qualified majority voting">qualified majority voting</a> in some decision-making among the member states, rather than relying exclusively on unanimity.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> It is less integrated than a federal state because it is not a state in its own right: sovereignty continues to flow 'from the bottom up', from the several peoples of the separate member states, rather than from a single undifferentiated whole. This is reflected in the fact that the member states remain the 'masters of the Treaties', retaining control over the allocation of competences to the Union through constitutional change (thus retaining so-called <i>Kompetenz-kompetenz</i>); in that they retain control of the use of armed force; they retain control of taxation; and in that they retain a right of unilateral withdrawal from the Union under Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union. In addition, the principle of <a href="/wiki/Subsidiarity" title="Subsidiarity">subsidiarity</a> requires that only those matters that need to be determined collectively are so determined.
</p><p>The European Union has seven principal decision-making bodies, its <a href="/wiki/Institutions_of_the_European_Union" title="Institutions of the European Union">institutions</a>: the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Auditors" title="European Court of Auditors">European Court of Auditors</a>. Competence in scrutinising and amending legislation is shared between the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament, while executive tasks are performed by the European Commission and in a limited capacity by the European Council (not to be confused with the aforementioned Council of the European Union). The <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> is determined by the European Central Bank. The interpretation and the application of EU law and the treaties are ensured by the Court of Justice of the European Union. The EU budget is scrutinised by the European Court of Auditors. There are also a number of ancillary bodies which advise the EU or operate in a specific area.
</p>
<ul><li>the <b><a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a></b>, which sets the <i>general political directions</i> and <i>priorities</i> of the Union by gathering together its member states' <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">heads of state</a>/<a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">government</a> (elected chief executives). The conclusions of its summits (held at least quarterly) are adopted by consensus.</li>
<li>the <b><a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a></b>, the only institution empowered to propose legislation, serves as the "Guardian of the Treaties". It consists of an <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">executive cabinet</a> of public officials, led by an <a href="/wiki/Indirect_election" title="Indirect election">indirectly elected</a> President. This <i>College of Commissioners</i> manages and directs the Commission's permanent civil service. It turns the consensus objectives of the European Council into <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">legislative proposals</a>.</li>
<li>the <b><a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a></b> brings together ministers of member states governments' departments. It serves to represent the various governments directly and its approval is required for any proposal to enter into law.</li>
<li>the <b><a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a></b> consists of 751 directly elected representatives. It shares with the Council of the EU equal legislative powers to amend, approve or reject Commission proposals for most areas of EU legislation. Its powers are limited in areas where member states' view sovereignty to be of primary concern (i.e. defence). It elects the Commission's President, must approve the College of Commissioners, and may vote to remove them collectively from office.</li>
<li>the <b><a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a></b> ensures the uniform application of EU law and resolves disputes between EU institutions and member states, and against EU institutions on behalf of individuals.</li>
<li>the <b><a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a></b> is responsible for monetary stability within member states.</li>
<li>the <b><a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Auditors" title="European Court of Auditors">European Court of Auditors</a></b> investigates the proper management of finances within both the EU entities and EU funding provided to its member states. As well as providing oversight and advice, it can refer unresolved issues to the European Court of Justice to arbitrate on any alleged irregularities.</li></ul>
<p>EU policy is in general promulgated by <a href="/wiki/Directive_(European_Union)" title="Directive (European Union)">EU directives</a>, which are then implemented in the <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">domestic legislation</a> of its <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member states</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Regulation_(European_Union)" title="Regulation (European Union)">EU regulations</a>, which are immediately enforceable in all member states. <a href="/wiki/Lobbying#European_Union" title="Lobbying">Lobbying</a> at EU level by special interest groups is regulated to try to balance the aspirations of private initiatives with public interest decision-making process<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Parliament">European Parliament</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg/330px-European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg/440px-European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="3389" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Parliament_Strasbourg_Hemicycle_-_Diliff.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Hemicycle" title="Hemicycle">hemicycle</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> in Strasbourg</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg/170px-David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg/255px-David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg/340px-David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg 2x" data-file-width="510" data-file-height="682" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:David_Maria_Sassoli.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Parliament" title="President of the European Parliament">President of the European Parliament</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Sassoli" title="David Sassoli">David Sassoli</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> is one of three <a href="/wiki/Legislature_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislature of the European Union">legislative institutions</a> of the EU, which together with the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a> is tasked with amending and approving the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">Commission</a>'s proposals.
The 751 <a href="/wiki/Member_of_the_European_Parliament" title="Member of the European Parliament">Members of the European Parliament</a> (MEPs) are directly <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Elections in the European Union">elected</a> by <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">EU citizens</a> every five years on the basis of <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>. Although MEPs are elected on a national basis, they sit according to <a href="/wiki/Political_groups_of_the_European_Parliament" title="Political groups of the European Parliament">political groups</a> rather than their nationality. Each country has a set number of seats and is divided into <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament_constituency" title="European Parliament constituency">sub-national constituencies</a> where this does not affect the proportional nature of the voting system.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Ordinary_legislative_procedure" class="mw-redirect" title="Ordinary legislative procedure">ordinary legislative procedure</a>, the European Commission proposes legislation, which requires the joint approval of the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to pass. This process applies to nearly all areas, including the <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union" title="Budget of the European Union">EU budget</a>. The Parliament is the final body to approve or reject the proposed membership of the Commission, and can attempt motions of censure on the Commission by appeal to the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">Court of Justice</a>. The <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Parliament" title="President of the European Parliament">President of the European Parliament</a> (currently <a href="/wiki/David_Sassoli" title="David Sassoli">David Sassoli</a>) carries out the role of speaker in Parliament and represents it externally. The President and <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_European_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Vice President of the European Parliament">Vice-Presidents</a> are elected by MEPs every two and a half years.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Institutions_Parliament_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Institutions_Parliament-152">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Council">European Council</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg/170px-Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg/255px-Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg/340px-Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1550" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Donald_Tusk_2013-12-19.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a></div></div></div>
<p>The European Council gives political direction to the EU. It convenes at least four times a year and comprises the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a> (currently <a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a>), the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the European Commission</a> and one representative per <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state</a> (either its <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> or <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>). The <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a> (currently <a href="/wiki/Federica_Mogherini" title="Federica Mogherini">Federica Mogherini</a>) also takes part in its meetings. It has been described by some as the Union's "supreme political authority".<sup id="cite_ref-How_work_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-How_work-153">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> It is actively involved in the negotiation of <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaty changes</a> and defines the EU's policy agenda and strategies.
</p><p>The European Council uses its leadership role to sort out disputes between member states and the institutions, and to resolve political crises and disagreements over controversial issues and policies. It acts externally as a "<a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">collective head of state</a>" and <a href="/wiki/Ratification" title="Ratification">ratifies</a> important documents (for example, international agreements and treaties).<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Tasks for the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Council" title="President of the European Council">President of the European Council</a> are ensuring the external representation of the EU,<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Press_Release_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Press_Release-155">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> driving consensus and resolving divergences among member states, both during meetings of the European Council and over the periods between them.
</p><p>The European Council should not be mistaken for the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, an international organisation independent of the EU based in Strasbourg.
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Council_of_the_European_Union">Council of the European Union</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/220px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/330px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg/440px-Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="858" data-file-height="614" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Lithuania_presidency_EU_stamp_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> held the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">Presidency of the Council of the European Union</a> in 2013.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a> (also called the "Council"<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> and the "Council of Ministers", its former title)<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> forms one half of the EU's legislature. It consists of a <a href="/wiki/Minister_(government)" title="Minister (government)">government minister</a> from each member state and meets in <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union#Configurations" title="Council of the European Union">different compositions depending on the policy area being addressed</a>. Notwithstanding its different configurations, it is considered to be one single body.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Institutions_Council_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Institutions_Council-158">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> In addition to its legislative functions, the Council also exercises <a href="/wiki/Executive_functions" title="Executive functions">executive functions</a> in relations to the <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a>.
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<p>In some policies, there are several member states that ally with strategic partners within the Union. <a href="/wiki/Visegrad_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Visegrad Group">Visegrad Group</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benelux" title="Benelux">Benelux</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Assembly" title="Baltic Assembly">Baltic Assembly</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Hanseatic_League" title="New Hanseatic League">New Hanseatic League</a> or <a href="/wiki/Craiova_Group" title="Craiova Group">Craiova Group</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Commission">European Commission</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> acts both as the EU's <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive arm</a>, responsible for the day-to-day running of the EU, and also the <a href="/wiki/Right_of_initiative_(legislative)" title="Right of initiative (legislative)">legislative initiator</a>, with the sole power to propose laws for debate.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Library_of_European_Parliament_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Library_of_European_Parliament-160">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> The Commission is 'guardian of the Treaties' and is responsible for their efficient operation and policing.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> It operates <i>de facto</i> as a <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet government</a>, with 28 <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner" title="European Commissioner">Commissioners</a> for different areas of policy, one from each member state, though Commissioners are bound to represent the interests of the EU as a whole rather than their home state.
</p><p>One of the 28 is the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission" title="President of the European Commission">President of the European Commission</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jean-Claude_Juncker" title="Jean-Claude Juncker">Jean-Claude Juncker</a> for 2014–2019), <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Commission#Appointment" title="President of the European Commission">appointed by the European Council</a>, subject to the Parliament's approval. After the President, the most prominent Commissioner is the <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a>, who is <i>ex-officio</i> a <a href="/wiki/Vice-President_of_the_European_Commission" title="Vice-President of the European Commission">Vice-President of the Commission</a> and is also chosen by the European Council.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> The other 26 Commissioners are subsequently appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a> in agreement with the nominated President. The 28 Commissioners as a single body are subject to approval (or otherwise) by vote of the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Budget">Budget</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union" title="Budget of the European Union">Budget of the European Union</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright" style=""><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
<div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black">
<div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:#A49"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1589.4544843865px; border-left-color:silver"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:silver"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:silver"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 212.51081731572px; border-left-color:#DC7"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#DC7"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#DC7"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 93.906250581749px; border-left-color:#4A9"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#4A9"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#4A9"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 6.291466725365px; border-left-color:#C67"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#C67"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#C67"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 307.76835371753px 100px 0; border-right-color:#8CE"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;right:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 100px 0;border-color:#8CE"></div>
</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>The 2011 EU budget (€141.9 bn)<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #8CE; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Cohesion and competitiveness for growth and employment (45%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #C67; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Direct aids and market related expenditures (31%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #4A9; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Rural development (11%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #DC7; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;EU as a global partner (6%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color:silver; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Administration (6%)</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #A49; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Citizenship, freedom, security and justice (1%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>The EU had an agreed budget of €120.7&#160;billion for the year 2007 and €864.3&#160;billion for the period 2007–2013,<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> representing 1.10% and 1.05% of the EU-27's <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">GNI</a> forecast for the respective periods. In 1960, the budget of the then European Economic Community was 0.03% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2010 budget of €141.5&#160;billion, the largest single expenditure item is "<i><a href="/wiki/Structural_Funds_and_Cohesion_Fund" title="Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund">cohesion &amp; competitiveness</a></i>" with around 45% of the total budget.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-167">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> Next comes "<i><a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a></i>" with approximately 31% of the total.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_167-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-167">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> "<i>Rural development, environment and <a href="/wiki/Common_Fisheries_Policy" title="Common Fisheries Policy">fisheries</a></i>" takes up around 11%.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_167-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-167">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> "<i>Administration</i>" accounts for around 6%.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_167-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-167">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> The "<i>EU as a global partner</i>" and "<i>citizenship, freedom, security and justice</i>" bring up the rear with approximately 6% and 1% respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-EUBudget2010_167-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUBudget2010-167">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Auditors" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of Auditors">Court of Auditors</a> is legally obliged to provide the Parliament and the Council with "a statement of assurance as to the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions".<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> The Court also gives opinions and proposals on financial legislation and anti-fraud actions.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Institutions_Auditors_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Institutions_Auditors-169">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> The Parliament uses this to decide whether to approve the Commission's handling of the budget.
</p><p>The European Court of Auditors has signed off the European Union accounts every year since 2007 and, while making it clear that the European Commission has more work to do, has highlighted that most of the errors take place at national level.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Court_of_Auditors_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Court_of_Auditors-170">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission-171">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup> In their report on 2009 the auditors found that five areas of Union expenditure, <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">agriculture</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Structural_Funds_and_Cohesion_Fund" title="Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund">cohesion fund</a>, were materially affected by error.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> The European Commission estimated in 2009 that the financial effect of irregularities was €1,863&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Competences">Competences</span></h3>
<p>EU member states retain all powers not explicitly handed to the European Union. In some areas the EU enjoys exclusive competence. These are areas in which member states have renounced any capacity to enact legislation. In other areas the EU and its member states share the competence to legislate. While both can legislate, member states can only legislate to the extent to which the EU has not. In other policy areas the EU can only co-ordinate, support and supplement member state action but cannot enact legislation with the aim of harmonising national laws.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>That a particular policy area falls into a certain category of competence is not necessarily indicative of what <a href="/wiki/Legislature_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislature of the European Union">legislative procedure</a> is used for enacting legislation within that policy area. Different legislative procedures are used within the same category of competence, and even with the same policy area.
</p><p>The distribution of competences in various policy areas between Member States and the Union is divided in the following three categories:
</p>
<table style="width:100%;background:none;">

<tbody><tr>
<td colspan="4" style="font-size:89%;text-align:center;">As outlined in <a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Consolidated_version_of_the_Treaty_on_the_Functioning_of_the_European_Union/Part_One:_Principles#TITLE_I:_CATEGORIES_AND_AREAS_OF_UNION_COMPETENCE" class="extiw" title="s:Consolidated version of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union/Part One: Principles">Title I of Part I of the consolidated Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a> <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar" style="float:right;font-size:100%;"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:EU_competences" title="Template:EU competences"><span title="View this template">view</span></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:EU_competences" title="Template talk:EU competences"><span title="Discuss this template">talk</span></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:EU_competences&amp;action=edit"><span title="Edit this template">edit</span></a></li></ul></div>

</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">European Union law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">Treaties of the European Union</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union</a></div>
<p>The EU is based on a series of <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_European_Union" title="Treaties of the European Union">treaties</a>. These first established the European Community and the EU, and then made amendments to those founding treaties.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> These are power-giving treaties which set broad policy goals and establish institutions with the necessary legal powers to implement those goals. These legal powers include the ability to enact legislation<sup id="cite_ref-art249_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art249-176">&#91;q&#93;</a></sup> which can directly affect all member states and their inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-Direct_Effect_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Direct_Effect-177">&#91;r&#93;</a></sup> The EU has <a href="/wiki/Legal_personality" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal personality">legal personality</a>, with the right to sign agreements and international treaties.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the principle of <a href="/wiki/Supremacy_(European_Union_law)" class="mw-redirect" title="Supremacy (European Union law)">supremacy</a>, national courts are required to enforce the treaties that their member states have ratified, and thus the laws enacted under them, even if doing so requires them to ignore conflicting national law, and (within limits) even constitutional provisions.<sup id="cite_ref-Supremacy_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Supremacy-179">&#91;s&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Direct_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct effect">direct effect</a> and supremacy doctrines were not explicitly set out the European Treaties but were developed by the Court of Justice itself over the 1960s, apparently under the influence of its then most influential judge, Frenchman <a href="/wiki/Robert_Lecourt" title="Robert Lecourt">Robert Lecourt</a><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Courts_of_Justice">Courts of Justice</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_(1674586821).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_%281674586821%29.jpg/220px-European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_%281674586821%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_%281674586821%29.jpg/330px-European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_%281674586821%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_%281674586821%29.jpg/440px-European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_%281674586821%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Court_of_Justice_-_Luxembourg_(1674586821).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">Court of Justice</a>, seated in Luxembourg City</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial branch</a> of the EU—formally called the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Justice_of_the_European_Union" title="Court of Justice of the European Union">Court of Justice of the European Union</a>—consists of two courts: the <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">Court of Justice</a> and the <a href="/wiki/General_Court_(European_Union)" title="General Court (European Union)">General Court</a><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup>
The Court of Justice primarily deals with cases taken by member states, the institutions, and <a href="/wiki/Preliminary_ruling" title="Preliminary ruling">cases referred to it</a> by the courts of member states.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> Because of the doctrines of <a href="/wiki/Direct_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct effect">direct effect</a> and supremacy, many judgments of the Court of Justice are automatically applicable within the internal legal orders of the member states.
</p><p>The General Court mainly deals with cases taken by individuals and companies directly before the EU's courts,<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> and the European Union Civil Service Tribunal adjudicates in disputes between the European Union and <a href="/wiki/European_Civil_Service" title="European Civil Service">its civil service</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> Decisions from the General Court can be appealed to the Court of Justice but only on a point of law.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fundamental_rights">Fundamental rights</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg/220px-Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg/330px-Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg/440px-Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1769" data-file-height="2359" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci_2018_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Parada_R%C3%B3wno%C5%9Bci" title="Parada Równości">Parada Równości</a> in Warsaw in 2018, when the Court of Justice declared that same-sex spouses have EU residence rights.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The treaties declare that the EU itself is "founded on the values of respect for <a href="/wiki/Human_dignity" class="mw-redirect" title="Human dignity">human dignity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberty" title="Liberty">freedom</a>, democracy, <a href="/wiki/Equality_before_the_law" title="Equality before the law">equality</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a> and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">minorities</a>&#160;... in a society in which pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail."<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Lisbon Treaty">Lisbon Treaty</a> gave legal effect to the <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union</a>. The charter is a codified catalogue of <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_right" class="mw-redirect" title="Fundamental right">fundamental rights</a> against which the EU's legal acts can be judged. It consolidates many rights which were previously recognised by the Court of Justice and derived from the "constitutional traditions common to the member states."<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> The Court of Justice has long recognised fundamental rights and has, on occasion, invalidated EU legislation based on its failure to adhere to those fundamental rights.<sup id="cite_ref-europarl-rights_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-europarl-rights-189">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Although signing the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a> (ECHR) is a condition for EU membership,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;t&#93;</a></sup> previously, the EU itself could not accede to the Convention as it is neither a state<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;u&#93;</a></sup> nor had the competence to accede.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;v&#93;</a></sup> The Lisbon Treaty and Protocol 14 to the ECHR have changed this: the former binds the EU to accede to the Convention while the latter formally permits it.
</p><p>Although, the EU is independent from Council of Europe, they share purpose and ideas especially on rule of law, human rights and democracy. Further <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Social_Charter" title="European Social Charter">European Social Charter</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Source_of_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Source of law">source of law</a> of <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights</a> are created by Council of Europe. The EU also promoted human rights issues in the wider world. The EU opposes the death penalty and has proposed its worldwide abolition. Abolition of the death penalty is a condition for EU membership.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Acts">Acts</span></h3>
<p>The main legal acts of the EU come in three forms: <a href="/wiki/Regulation_(European_Union)" title="Regulation (European Union)">regulations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Directive_(European_Union)" title="Directive (European Union)">directives</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Decision_(European_Union)" title="Decision (European Union)">decisions</a>. Regulations become law in all member states the moment they come into force, without the requirement for any implementing measures,<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;w&#93;</a></sup> and automatically override conflicting domestic provisions.<sup id="cite_ref-art249_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art249-176">&#91;q&#93;</a></sup> Directives require member states to achieve a certain result while leaving them discretion as to how to achieve the result. The details of how they are to be implemented are left to member states.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;x&#93;</a></sup> When the time limit for implementing directives passes, they may, under certain conditions, have <a href="/wiki/Direct_effect" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct effect">direct effect</a> in national law against member states.
</p><p>Decisions offer an alternative to the two above modes of legislation. They are legal acts which only apply to specified individuals, companies or a particular member state. They are most often used in <a href="/wiki/Competition_law" title="Competition law">competition law</a>, or on rulings on State Aid, but are also frequently used for procedural or administrative matters within the institutions. Regulations, directives, and decisions are of equal legal value and apply without any formal hierarchy.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Justice_and_home_affairs">Justice and home affairs</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Area_of_freedom,_security_and_justice" title="Area of freedom, security and justice">Area of freedom, security and justice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">Citizenship of the European Union</a></div>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg/240px-OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg/360px-OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg/480px-OffeneGrenzeNiederndorf-Oberaudorf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="450" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The borders inside the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a> between Germany and Austria
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europol_Building;_The_Hague;_Eisenhowerlaan;_Statenkwartier;_2014;_photo_nr._41860.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Europol_Building%3B_The_Hague%3B_Eisenhowerlaan%3B_Statenkwartier%3B_2014%3B_photo_nr._41860.jpg/240px-Europol_Building%3B_The_Hague%3B_Eisenhowerlaan%3B_Statenkwartier%3B_2014%3B_photo_nr._41860.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Europol_Building%3B_The_Hague%3B_Eisenhowerlaan%3B_Statenkwartier%3B_2014%3B_photo_nr._41860.jpg/360px-Europol_Building%3B_The_Hague%3B_Eisenhowerlaan%3B_Statenkwartier%3B_2014%3B_photo_nr._41860.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Europol_Building%3B_The_Hague%3B_Eisenhowerlaan%3B_Statenkwartier%3B_2014%3B_photo_nr._41860.jpg/480px-Europol_Building%3B_The_Hague%3B_Eisenhowerlaan%3B_Statenkwartier%3B_2014%3B_photo_nr._41860.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
