</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px"><div style="width: 182px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eurojust-building-2017.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Eurojust-building-2017.jpg/270px-Eurojust-building-2017.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Eurojust-building-2017.jpg/405px-Eurojust-building-2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Eurojust-building-2017.jpg/540px-Eurojust-building-2017.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Eurojust" title="Eurojust">Eurojust</a> Headquarters in The Hague, Netherlands
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 82px"><div style="width: 82px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 80px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Warsaw_Spire,_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Warsaw_Spire%2C_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg/120px-Warsaw_Spire%2C_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="80" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Warsaw_Spire%2C_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg/180px-Warsaw_Spire%2C_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Warsaw_Spire%2C_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg/240px-Warsaw_Spire%2C_Poland_23_June_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4724" data-file-height="7087" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Seat of <a href="/wiki/Frontex" class="mw-redirect" title="Frontex">Frontex</a> in <a href="/wiki/Warsaw" title="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<p>Since the creation of the EU in 1993, it has developed its competencies in the area of justice and home affairs; initially at an intergovernmental level and later by supranationalism. Accordingly, the Union has legislated in areas such as <a href="/wiki/European_Arrest_Warrant" title="European Arrest Warrant">extradition</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> family law,<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> asylum law,<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> and criminal justice.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> Prohibitions against sexual and nationality discrimination have a long standing in the treaties.<sup id="cite_ref-art39/141_Rome_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art39/141_Rome-201">&#91;y&#93;</a></sup> In more recent years, these have been supplemented by powers to legislate against discrimination based on race, religion, disability, age, and sexual orientation.<sup id="cite_ref-art2(7)_Amsterdam_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art2(7)_Amsterdam-202">&#91;z&#93;</a></sup> By virtue of these powers, the EU has enacted legislation on <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexual discrimination</a> in the work-place, <a href="/wiki/Ageism" title="Ageism">age discrimination</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racial discrimination</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;aa&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Union has also established agencies to co-ordinate police, prosecutorial and immigrations controls across the member states: <a href="/wiki/Europol" title="Europol">Europol</a> for co-operation of police forces,<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eurojust" title="Eurojust">Eurojust</a> for co-operation between prosecutors,<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Frontex" class="mw-redirect" title="Frontex">Frontex</a> for co-operation between border control authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> The EU also operates the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Information_System" title="Schengen Information System">Schengen Information System</a><sup id="cite_ref-Internal_borders_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Internal_borders-22">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> which provides a common database for police and immigration authorities. This co-operation had to particularly be developed with the advent of open borders through the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Agreement" title="Schengen Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a> and the associated cross border crime.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_European_Union" title="Foreign relations of the European Union">Foreign relations of the European Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_External_Action_Service" title="European External Action Service">European External Action Service</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_(34502607780).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_%2834502607780%29.jpg/220px-President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_%2834502607780%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_%2834502607780%29.jpg/330px-President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_%2834502607780%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_%2834502607780%29.jpg/440px-President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_%2834502607780%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:President_Trump%27s_Trip_Abroad_(34502607780).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Donald_Tusk" title="Donald Tusk">Donald Tusk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Claude_Juncker" title="Jean-Claude Juncker">Jean-Claude Juncker</a> with U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>, 2017.</div></div></div>
<p>Foreign policy co-operation between member states dates from the establishment of the Community in 1957, when member states negotiated as a bloc in international trade negotiations under the <a href="/wiki/EU%27s_common_commercial_policy" class="mw-redirect" title="EU&#39;s common commercial policy">EU's common commercial policy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> Steps for a more wide-ranging co-ordination in foreign relations began in 1970 with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/European_Political_Cooperation" title="European Political Cooperation">European Political Cooperation</a> which created an informal consultation process between member states with the aim of forming common foreign policies. It was not, however, until 1987 when European Political Cooperation was introduced on a formal basis by the <a href="/wiki/Single_European_Act" title="Single European Act">Single European Act</a>. EPC was renamed as the <a href="/wiki/Common_Foreign_and_Security_Policy" title="Common Foreign and Security Policy">Common Foreign and Security Policy</a> (CFSP) by the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EPC_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EPC-208">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The aims of the CFSP are to promote both the EU's own interests and those of the <a href="/wiki/International_community" title="International community">international community</a> as a whole, including the furtherance of international co-operation, respect for human rights, democracy, and the rule of law.<sup id="cite_ref-art11_Union_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art11_Union-209">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> The CFSP requires unanimity among the member states on the appropriate policy to follow on any particular issue. The unanimity and difficult issues treated under the CFSP sometimes lead to disagreements, such as those which occurred over the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">war in Iraq</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Iraq_statement_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Iraq_statement-210">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The coordinator and representative of the CFSP within the EU is the <a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a> who speaks on behalf of the EU in foreign policy and defence matters, and has the task of articulating the positions expressed by the member states on these fields of policy into a common alignment. The High Representative heads up the <a href="/wiki/European_External_Action_Service" title="European External Action Service">European External Action Service</a> (EEAS), a unique EU department<sup id="cite_ref-23Oct_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23Oct-211">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> that has been officially implemented and operational since 1 December 2010 on the occasion of the first anniversary of the entry into force of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> The EEAS will serve as a foreign ministry and <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_corps" title="Diplomatic corps">diplomatic corps</a> for the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_EEAS_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_EEAS-213">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 236px"><div style="width: 236px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 234px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Membreupm.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Membreupm.png/351px-Membreupm.png" decoding="async" width="234" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/20/Membreupm.png 1.5x" data-file-width="411" data-file-height="211" /></a></div></div>

</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 208px"><div style="width: 208px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 206px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou,_China.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou%2C_China.jpg/309px-Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou%2C_China.jpg" decoding="async" width="206" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou%2C_China.jpg/463px-Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou%2C_China.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou%2C_China.jpg/617px-Prime_Minister_Narendra_Modi_at_the_G20_Summit_in_Hangzhou%2C_China.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1745" data-file-height="1018" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>The EU participates in all <a href="/wiki/G8" class="mw-redirect" title="G8">G8</a> and <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a> summits. (<a href="/wiki/2016_G20_Hangzhou_summit" title="2016 G20 Hangzhou summit">G20 summit in Hangzhou, 2016</a>)
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px"><div style="width: 182px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:German_Foreign_Minister_Steinmeier,_EU_High_Representative_Mogherini,_and_Iranian_Foreign_Minister_Zarif_Stand_for_a_Group_Photo_After_EU,_P5%2B1_Reached_Iran_Nuclear_Agreement_in_Austria.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/German_Foreign_Minister_Steinmeier%2C_EU_High_Representative_Mogherini%2C_and_Iranian_Foreign_Minister_Zarif_Stand_for_a_Group_Photo_After_EU%2C_P5%2B1_Reached_Iran_Nuclear_Agreement_in_Austria.jpg/270px-thumbnail.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/German_Foreign_Minister_Steinmeier%2C_EU_High_Representative_Mogherini%2C_and_Iranian_Foreign_Minister_Zarif_Stand_for_a_Group_Photo_After_EU%2C_P5%2B1_Reached_Iran_Nuclear_Agreement_in_Austria.jpg/405px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/German_Foreign_Minister_Steinmeier%2C_EU_High_Representative_Mogherini%2C_and_Iranian_Foreign_Minister_Zarif_Stand_for_a_Group_Photo_After_EU%2C_P5%2B1_Reached_Iran_Nuclear_Agreement_in_Austria.jpg/540px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4081" data-file-height="2720" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/High_Representative_of_the_Union_for_Foreign_Affairs_and_Security_Policy" title="High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy">High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federica_Mogherini" title="Federica Mogherini">Federica Mogherini</a>, after reaching in <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a> the <a href="/wiki/Iran_nuclear_deal_framework" title="Iran nuclear deal framework">Iran nuclear deal framework</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 189.33333333333px"><div style="width: 189.33333333333px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 187.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_(9).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_%289%29.jpg/281px-EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_%289%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="188" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_%289%29.jpg/421px-EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_%289%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_%289%29.jpg/562px-EU-Japan_EPA_Signing_%289%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="513" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Shinz%C5%8D_Abe" title="Shinzō Abe">Shinzō Abe</a>, Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker after signing the <a href="https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC%E3%83%BBEU%E7%B5%8C%E6%B8%88%E9%80%A3%E6%90%BA%E5%8D%94%E5%AE%9A" class="extiw" title="ja:日本・EU経済連携協定">EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<p>Besides the emerging international policy of the European Union, the international influence of the EU is also felt through <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">enlargement</a>. The perceived benefits of becoming a member of the EU act as an incentive for both political and economic reform in states wishing to fulfil the EU's accession criteria, and are considered an important factor contributing to the reform of European formerly Communist countries.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>762</span></sup> This influence on the internal affairs of other countries is generally referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Soft_power" title="Soft power">soft power</a>", as opposed to military "hard power".<sup id="cite_ref-Soft_Power_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soft_Power-215">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The European Union has concluded <a href="/wiki/European_Union_free_trade_agreements" title="European Union free trade agreements">free trade agreements</a> (FTAs)<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> and other agreements with a trade component with many countries worldwide and is negotiating with many others.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Defence">Defence</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Common_Security_and_Defence_Policy" title="Common Security and Defence Policy">Common Security and Defence Policy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_(29510554308).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_%2829510554308%29.jpg/220px-2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_%2829510554308%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_%2829510554308%29.jpg/330px-2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_%2829510554308%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_%2829510554308%29.jpg/440px-2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_%2829510554308%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6979" data-file-height="4653" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2018_NATO_Summit_in_Brussels_(29510554308).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Out of the 28 EU member states, 22 are also members of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. Another three NATO members are EU applicants – Albania, Montenegro and Turkey.</div></div></div>
<p>The predecessors of the European Union were not devised as a military alliance because <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> was largely seen as appropriate and sufficient for defence purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilkinson2007100_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilkinson2007100-218">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> 22 EU members are members of NATO<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> while the remaining member states follow policies of <a href="/wiki/Neutrality_(international_relations)" class="mw-redirect" title="Neutrality (international relations)">neutrality</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">Western European Union</a>, a military alliance with a mutual defence clause, was disbanded in 2010 as its role had been transferred to the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a> (SIPRI), the United Kingdom spent $61 billion on defence in 2014, placing it fifth in the world, while France spent $53 billion, the sixth largest.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> Together, the UK and France account for approximately 40 per cent of European countries' defence budget and 50 per cent of their military capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> Both are officially recognised <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapon states</a> holding <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent seats</a> on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>. Most EU member states opposed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Nuclear Weapon Ban Treaty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna,_2009.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna%2C_2009.jpg/220px-Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna%2C_2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna%2C_2009.jpg/330px-Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna%2C_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna%2C_2009.jpg/440px-Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna%2C_2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2872" data-file-height="2031" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Verni_and_Tsezar%27_Kunikov_in_Varna,_2009.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Bulgarian fleet in <a href="/wiki/Varna" title="Varna">Varna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a> in 1999, the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a> agreed that "the Union must have the capacity for autonomous action, backed by credible military forces, the means to decide to use them, and the readiness to do so, in order to respond to international crises without prejudice to actions by NATO". To that end, a number of efforts were made to increase the EU's military capability, notably the <a href="/wiki/Helsinki_Headline_Goal" title="Helsinki Headline Goal">Helsinki Headline Goal</a> process. After much discussion, the most concrete result was the <a href="/wiki/EU_Battlegroup" title="EU Battlegroup">EU Battlegroups</a> initiative, each of which is planned to be able to deploy quickly about 1500&#160;personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Capabilities_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Capabilities-225">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/EUFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="EUFOR">EU forces</a> have been deployed on peacekeeping missions from middle and northern Africa to the <a href="/wiki/Western_Balkans" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Balkans">western Balkans</a> and western Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Operations_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Operations-226">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> EU military operations are supported by a number of bodies, including the <a href="/wiki/European_Defence_Agency" title="European Defence Agency">European Defence Agency</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Satellite_Centre" title="European Union Satellite Centre">European Union Satellite Centre</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Military_Staff" title="European Union Military Staff">European Union Military Staff</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_Structures_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_Structures-227">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Frontex" class="mw-redirect" title="Frontex">Frontex</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Agencies_of_the_European_Union" title="Agencies of the European Union">agency of the EU</a> established to manage the cooperation between national <a href="/wiki/Border_guard" title="Border guard">border guards</a> securing its external <a href="/wiki/Border" title="Border">borders</a>. It aims to detect and stop illegal immigration, <a href="/wiki/Human_trafficking" title="Human trafficking">human trafficking</a> and terrorist infiltration. In 2015 the European Commission presented its proposal for a new European Border and Coast Guard Agency having a stronger role and mandate along with national authorities for border management. In an EU consisting of 28 members, substantial security and defence co-operation is increasingly relying on collaboration among all member states.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Humanitarian_aid">Humanitarian aid</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_European_Civil_Protection_and_Humanitarian_Aid_Operations" title="Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations">Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ECHO_plane.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ECHO_plane.jpg/220px-ECHO_plane.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ECHO_plane.jpg/330px-ECHO_plane.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ECHO_plane.jpg/440px-ECHO_plane.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="535" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:ECHO_plane.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>If considered collectively, EU member states are the largest contributor of <a href="/wiki/List_of_development_aid_country_donors" title="List of development aid country donors">foreign aid</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-GHA_report_2014_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GHA_report_2014-229">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OECD_aid_report_2013_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_aid_report_2013-230">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/ECHO_(European_Commission)" class="mw-redirect" title="ECHO (European Commission)">European Commission's Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection department</a>, or "ECHO", provides <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_aid" title="Humanitarian aid">humanitarian aid</a> from the EU to <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing countries</a>. In 2012, its budget amounted to €874 million, 51% of the budget went to Africa and 20% to Asia, Latin America, the Caribbean and Pacific, and 20% to the Middle East and Mediterranean.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Humanitarian aid is financed directly by the budget (70%) as part of the financial instruments for external action and also by the <a href="/wiki/European_Development_Fund" title="European Development Fund">European Development Fund</a> (30%).<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-232">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> The EU's external action financing is divided into 'geographic' instruments and 'thematic' instruments.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-232">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> The 'geographic' instruments provide aid through the <a href="/wiki/Development_Cooperation_Instrument" title="Development Cooperation Instrument">Development Cooperation Instrument</a> (DCI, €16.9 billion, 2007–2013), which must spend 95% of its budget on <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> (ODA), and from the <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_and_Partnership_Instrument" class="mw-redirect" title="European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument">European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument</a> (ENPI), which contains some relevant programmes.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_232-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-232">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> The European Development Fund (EDF, €22.7 billion for the period 2008–2013 and €30.5 billion for the period 2014-2020) is made up of voluntary contributions by member states, but there is pressure to merge the EDF into the budget-financed instruments to encourage increased contributions to match the 0.7% target and allow the <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">European Parliament</a> greater oversight.<sup id="cite_ref-ODI_232-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-232">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2016, the average among EU countries was 0.4% and five had met or exceeded the 0.7% target: Denmark, Germany, Luxembourg, Sweden and the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_and_global_influence">Regional and global influence</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Eurosphere" title="Eurosphere">Eurosphere</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Union_as_an_emerging_superpower" title="European Union as an emerging superpower">European Union as an emerging superpower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Europeanisation" title="Europeanisation">Europeanisation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_Policy" title="European Neighbourhood Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg/170px-Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg/255px-Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg/340px-Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="2816" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Eiffel_Tower_wearing_Europe_colors_-_panoramio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a>, Paris</div></div></div>
<p>Because of its ability to shape rules and norms on a global level as well as its attempts to influence neighbouring countries, the EU has been called an emerging or potential superpower by scholars and academics like T. R. Reid,<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> Andrew Reding,<sup id="cite_ref-A._R._236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-A._R.-236">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Moravcsik" title="Andrew Moravcsik">Andrew Moravcsik</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mark_Leonard_(director)" title="Mark Leonard (director)">Mark Leonard</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Rifkin" title="Jeremy Rifkin">Jeremy Rifkin</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_McCormick_(political_scientist)" title="John McCormick (political scientist)">John McCormick</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup> and some politicians like <a href="/wiki/Romano_Prodi" title="Romano Prodi">Romano Prodi</a><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> They believe that the EU is a superpower, or will become one, in the 21st century&#160;&#8211;&#32; while noting that, for them, the concept of "superpower" has changed to one of <a href="/wiki/Soft_power" title="Soft power">soft power</a> rather than the hard (military) superpowers of the 20th century.
</p><p>The EU uses foreign relations instruments like the <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_Policy" title="European Neighbourhood Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a> which seeks to tie those countries to the east and south of the European territory of the EU to the Union. These countries, primarily developing countries, include some who seek to one day become either a <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a>, or more closely integrated with the European Union. The EU offers financial assistance to countries within the European Neighbourhood, so long as they meet the strict conditions of government reform, economic reform and other issues surrounding positive transformation. This process is normally underpinned by an Action Plan, as agreed by both Brussels and the target country.
</p><p>Critics of the concept of the EU as an emerging superpower point to the lack of either a strong European military or of unified EU foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_European_Union" title="Economy of the European Union">Economy of the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regional_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Regional policy of the European Union">Regional policy of the European Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gross_domestic_product_(GDP)_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_(PPS)_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average,_by_NUTS_2_regions,_2015.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Gross_domestic_product_%28GDP%29_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_%28PPS%29_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average%2C_by_NUTS_2_regions%2C_2015.png/300px-Gross_domestic_product_%28GDP%29_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_%28PPS%29_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average%2C_by_NUTS_2_regions%2C_2015.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="425" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Gross_domestic_product_%28GDP%29_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_%28PPS%29_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average%2C_by_NUTS_2_regions%2C_2015.png/450px-Gross_domestic_product_%28GDP%29_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_%28PPS%29_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average%2C_by_NUTS_2_regions%2C_2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Gross_domestic_product_%28GDP%29_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_%28PPS%29_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average%2C_by_NUTS_2_regions%2C_2015.png/600px-Gross_domestic_product_%28GDP%29_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_%28PPS%29_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average%2C_by_NUTS_2_regions%2C_2015.png 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1449" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gross_domestic_product_(GDP)_per_inhabitant_in_purchasing_power_standards_(PPS)_in_relation_to_the_EU-28_average,_by_NUTS_2_regions,_2015.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gross domestic product (GDP) per inhabitant in purchasing power standards (PPS) in relation to the EU-28 average, by NUTS 2 regions, 2017</div></div></div>
<div class="thumbinner tright" style="width:300px; margin-left: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; border:1px solid #ddd;"><div class="timeline-wrapper"><map name="timeline_7e04d1e0c1b98db9997f07d2701c85a5"></map><img usemap="#timeline_7e04d1e0c1b98db9997f07d2701c85a5" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/timeline/7e04d1e0c1b98db9997f07d2701c85a5.png" /></div><div class="thumbcaption">The five largest economies in the world according to the <a href="/wiki/IMF" class="mw-redirect" title="IMF">IMF</a> by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">Nominal GDP</a> in 2018<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup></div></div>
<p>The European Union has established a <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">single market</a> across the territory of all its members representing 512 million citizens. In 2017, the EU had a combined GDP of $21 trillion <a href="/wiki/International_dollar" class="mw-redirect" title="International dollar">international dollars</a>, a 17% share of <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by GDP">global gross domestic product by purchasing power parity (PPP)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2011-IMG-GDP_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2011-IMG-GDP-245">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> As a political entity the European Union is represented in the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO). EU member states own the estimated second largest after the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> (<a href="/wiki/US$" class="mw-redirect" title="US$">US$</a>98.2 trillion) <a href="/wiki/Net_wealth" class="mw-redirect" title="Net wealth">net wealth</a> in the world, equal to 25% (<a href="/wiki/US$" class="mw-redirect" title="US$">US$</a>78 trillion) of the $317 trillion (~€280 trillion<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup>) global wealth.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>19 member states have joined a monetary union known as the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a>, which uses the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">Euro</a> as a single currency. The currency union represents 342 million EU citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market-248">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> The euro is the second largest <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a> as well as the second most traded currency in the world after the <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">United States dollar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Of the top <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">500 largest corporations in the world measured by revenue</a> in 2010, 161 have their headquarters in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> In 2016, unemployment in the EU stood at 8.9%<sup id="cite_ref-UNEMP_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNEMP-253">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> while inflation was at 2.2%, and the current account balance at −0.9% of GDP. The average annual net earnings in the European Union was around €24,000 (US$30,000)<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> in 2015, which was about 70% of that in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There is a significant variation in Nominal GDP per capita within individual EU states. The difference between the richest and poorest regions (281 NUTS-2 regions of the <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics</a>) ranged, in 2017, from 15% (Severozapaden, Bulgaria) of the EU28 average (€30,000) to 700% (Inner London – West, UK), or from €4,600 to €209,900.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Structural_Funds_and_Cohesion_Funds" class="mw-redirect" title="Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds">Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds</a> are supporting the development of underdeveloped regions of the EU. Such regions are primarily located in the states of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">central</a> and southern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Business2000_Funds_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Business2000_Funds-258">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> Several funds provide emergency aid, support for candidate members to transform their country to conform to the EU's standard (<a href="/wiki/Phare" title="Phare">Phare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Instrument_for_Structural_Policies_for_Pre-Accession" title="Instrument for Structural Policies for Pre-Accession">ISPA</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Special_Accession_Programme_for_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development" title="Special Accession Programme for Agriculture and Rural Development">SAPARD</a>), and support to the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (<a href="/wiki/Technical_Aid_to_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Technical Aid to the Commonwealth of Independent States">TACIS</a>). TACIS has now become part of the worldwide <a href="/wiki/EuropeAid_Co-operation_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="EuropeAid Co-operation Office">EuropeAid</a> programme. EU <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">research and technological framework programmes</a> sponsor research conducted by consortia from all EU members to work towards a single <a href="/wiki/European_Research_Area" title="European Research Area">European Research Area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Euractiv_FP7_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Euractiv_FP7-259">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><br />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internal_market">Internal market</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">European Single Market</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:91px;max-width:91px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:125px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Eirepas.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/89px-Eirepas.JPG" decoding="async" width="89" height="125" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/134px-Eirepas.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Eirepas.JPG/178px-Eirepas.JPG 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="842" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:197px;max-width:197px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:125px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Croatian_driving_licence.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Croatian_driving_licence.jpg/195px-Croatian_driving_licence.jpg" decoding="async" width="195" height="126" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Croatian_driving_licence.jpg/293px-Croatian_driving_licence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Croatian_driving_licence.jpg/390px-Croatian_driving_licence.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="322" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:290px;max-width:290px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:64px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:SK-number-plate-2004.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/SK-number-plate-2004.svg/288px-SK-number-plate-2004.svg.png" decoding="async" width="288" height="64" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/SK-number-plate-2004.svg/432px-SK-number-plate-2004.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/SK-number-plate-2004.svg/576px-SK-number-plate-2004.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1748" data-file-height="389" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Clockwise from top left: A <a href="/wiki/Passports_of_the_European_Union" title="Passports of the European Union">standardised passport</a> design, displaying the name of the member state, the national <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms" title="Coat of arms">arms</a> and the words "European Union" given in their official language(s). (Irish model), Croatian version of an <a href="/wiki/European_driving_licence" title="European driving licence">EU driving licence card</a> with the <a href="/wiki/EU_flag" class="mw-redirect" title="EU flag">EU flag</a> on it, The common EU format of <a href="/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_Europe" title="Vehicle registration plates of Europe">vehicle registration plate</a> (Slovak version pictured)</div></div></div></div>
<p>Two of the original core objectives of the European Economic Community were the development of a common market, subsequently becoming a <a href="/wiki/Single_market" title="Single market">single market</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Customs_Union" title="European Union Customs Union">customs union</a> between its member states. The single market involves <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">the free circulation of goods, capital, people, and services within the EU</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_248-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market-248">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> and the customs union involves the application of a <a href="/wiki/Common_external_tariff" title="Common external tariff">common external tariff</a> on all goods entering the market. Once goods have been admitted into the market they cannot be subjected to customs duties, discriminatory taxes or <a href="/wiki/Import_quota" title="Import quota">import quotas</a>, as they travel internally. The non-EU member states of <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liechtenstein" title="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> participate in the single market but not in the customs union.<sup id="cite_ref-EEA_132-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EEA-132">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> Half the trade in the EU is covered by legislation harmonised by the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_G_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_G-260">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Free movement of capital is intended to permit movement of investments such as property purchases and buying of shares between countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_C_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_C-261">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> Until the drive towards <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_monetary_union" title="Economic and monetary union">economic and monetary union</a> the development of the capital provisions had been slow. Post-Maastricht there has been a rapidly developing corpus of ECJ judgements regarding this initially neglected freedom. The free movement of capital is unique insofar as it is granted equally to non-member states.
</p><p>The free movement of persons means that <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">EU citizens</a> can move freely between member states to live, work, study or retire in another country. This required the lowering of administrative formalities and recognition of professional qualifications of other states.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_P_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_P-262">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The free movement of services and of establishment allows self-employed persons to move between member states to provide services on a temporary or permanent basis. While services account for 60–70% of GDP, legislation in the area is not as developed as in other areas. This lacuna has been addressed by the recently passed <a href="/wiki/Directive_on_services_in_the_internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Directive on services in the internal market">Directive on services in the internal market</a> which aims to liberalise the cross border provision of services.<sup id="cite_ref-Europa_Single_Market_S_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Europa_Single_Market_S-263">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> According to the Treaty the provision of services is a residual freedom that only applies if no other freedom is being exercised.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monetary_union">Monetary union</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_and_Monetary_Union_of_the_European_Union" title="Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union">Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Banking_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Banking Union">Banking Union</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:113px;max-width:113px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:184px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg/111px-European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg" decoding="async" width="111" height="184" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg/167px-European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg/222px-European_Central_Bank_-_building_under_construction_-_Frankfurt_-_Germany_-_13.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3622" data-file-height="6000" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:175px;max-width:175px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:184px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:BlueEurozone.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/173px-BlueEurozone.svg.png" decoding="async" width="173" height="185" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/260px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/BlueEurozone.svg/346px-BlueEurozone.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="645" data-file-height="690" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Left: The <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="Seat of the European Central Bank">seat of the European Central Bank</a> in <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt" title="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>. Right: 19 of the 28 EU member states have adopted the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> as their <a href="/wiki/Legal_tender" title="Legal tender">legal tender</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> (dark blue) represents 340 million people. The euro is the second-largest reserve currency in the world and the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_traded_currencies" class="mw-redirect" title="List of most traded currencies">2nd-most-traded currency</a>.</div></div></div></div>
<p>The creation of a <a href="/wiki/European_Currency_Unit" title="European Currency Unit">European single currency</a> became an official objective of the European Economic Community in 1969. In 1992, having negotiated the structure and procedures of a currency union, the member states signed the <a href="/wiki/Maastricht_Treaty" title="Maastricht Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> and were legally bound to fulfil the agreed-on rules including the <a href="/wiki/Euro_convergence_criteria" title="Euro convergence criteria">convergence criteria</a> if they wanted to join the <a href="/wiki/Currency_union" title="Currency union">monetary union</a>. The states wanting to participate had first to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Exchange_Rate_Mechanism" title="European Exchange Rate Mechanism">European Exchange Rate Mechanism</a>.
</p><p>In 1999 the currency union started, first as an accounting currency with <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_euro" title="History of the euro">eleven member states</a> joining. In 2002, the currency was fully put into place, when <a href="/wiki/Euro_banknotes" title="Euro banknotes">euro notes</a> and coins were issued and national currencies began to phase out in the eurozone, which by then consisted of 12 member states. The eurozone (constituted by the EU member states which have adopted the euro) has since grown to 19 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;ab&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lagarde,_Christine_(official_portrait_2011).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Lagarde%2C_Christine_%28official_portrait_2011%29.jpg/200px-Lagarde%2C_Christine_%28official_portrait_2011%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="257" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Lagarde%2C_Christine_%28official_portrait_2011%29.jpg/300px-Lagarde%2C_Christine_%28official_portrait_2011%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Lagarde%2C_Christine_%28official_portrait_2011%29.jpg/400px-Lagarde%2C_Christine_%28official_portrait_2011%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1541" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Lagarde,_Christine_(official_portrait_2011).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Christine_Lagarde" title="Christine Lagarde">Christine Lagarde</a>, designated <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="President of the European Central Bank">President of the European Central Bank</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The euro, and the monetary policies of those who have adopted it in agreement with the EU, are under the control of the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a> (ECB).<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> The ECB is the central bank for the eurozone, and thus controls <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> in that area with an agenda to maintain <a href="/wiki/Price_stability" title="Price stability">price stability</a>. It is at the centre of the <a href="/wiki/European_System_of_Central_Banks" title="European System of Central Banks">European System of Central Banks</a>, which comprehends all EU national central banks and is controlled by its General Council, consisting of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_European_Central_Bank" title="President of the European Central Bank">President of the ECB</a>, who is appointed by the European Council, the Vice-President of the ECB, and the governors of the national central banks of all 28 EU member states.<sup id="cite_ref-ECB_org_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECB_org-267">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_System_of_Financial_Supervision" title="European System of Financial Supervision">European System of Financial Supervision</a> is an institutional architecture of the EU's framework of financial supervision composed by three authorities: the <a href="/wiki/European_Banking_Authority" title="European Banking Authority">European Banking Authority</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Insurance_and_Occupational_Pensions_Authority" title="European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority">European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Securities_and_Markets_Authority" title="European Securities and Markets Authority">European Securities and Markets Authority</a>. To complement this framework, there is also a <a href="/wiki/European_Systemic_Risk_Board" title="European Systemic Risk Board">European Systemic Risk Board</a> under the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">ECB</a>. The aim of this financial control system is to ensure the economic stability of the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>To prevent the joining states from getting into financial trouble or crisis after entering the monetary union, they were obliged in the Maastricht treaty to fulfil important financial obligations and procedures, especially to show budgetary discipline and a high degree of sustainable economic convergence, as well as to avoid excessive government deficits and limit the government debt to a sustainable level.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_the_European_Union" title="Energy policy of the European Union">Energy policy of the European Union</a></div>

</div>
</div>
<p>In 2006, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_2005" title="Treaty of Accession 2005">EU-27</a> had a gross inland energy consumption of 1,825&#160;million tonnes of oil equivalent (toe).<sup id="cite_ref-EurostatEnergy_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EurostatEnergy-270">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> Around 46% of the energy consumed was produced within the member states while 54% was imported.<sup id="cite_ref-EurostatEnergy_270-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EurostatEnergy-270">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> In these statistics, nuclear energy is treated as <a href="/wiki/Primary_energy" title="Primary energy">primary energy</a> produced in the EU, regardless of the source of the uranium, of which less than 3% is produced in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-Euratom2007_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Euratom2007-271">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The EU has had legislative power in the area of energy policy for most of its existence; this has its roots in the original <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a>. The introduction of a mandatory and comprehensive European energy policy was approved at the meeting of the European Council in October 2005, and the first draft policy was published in January 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Q&amp;A_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Q&amp;A-272">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The EU has five key points in its energy policy: increase competition in the <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">internal market</a>, encourage investment and boost interconnections between electricity grids; diversify energy resources with better systems to respond to a crisis; establish a new treaty framework for energy co-operation with Russia while improving relations with energy-rich states in Central Asia<sup id="cite_ref-oies_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oies-273">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> and North Africa; use existing energy supplies more efficiently while increasing <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_commercialisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Renewable energy commercialisation">renewable energy commercialisation</a>; and finally increase funding for new energy technologies.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Q&amp;A_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Q&amp;A-272">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2007, EU countries as a whole imported 82% of their oil, 57% of their natural gas<sup id="cite_ref-low_carb_prop_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-low_carb_prop-274">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> and 97.48% of their uranium<sup id="cite_ref-Euratom2007_271-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Euratom2007-271">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> demands. There is a strong <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">dependence on Russian energy</a> that the EU has been attempting to reduce.<sup id="cite_ref-Energy_Russia_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Energy_Russia-275">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png/220px-Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png/330px-Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png/440px-Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1604" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_Completed_Motorways_Dec_2012.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Approximate extent of completed motorway network in Europe as of March&#160;2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Union&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Transport" title="European Commissioner for Transport">European Commissioner for Transport</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Industry_and_Entrepreneurship" title="European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship">European Commissioner for Industry and Entrepreneurship</a>, and <a href="/wiki/European_Investment_Bank" title="European Investment Bank">European Investment Bank</a></div><p>The EU is working to improve cross-border infrastructure within the EU, for example through the <a href="/wiki/Trans-European_Networks" title="Trans-European Networks">Trans-European Networks</a> (TEN). Projects under TEN include the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>, <a href="/wiki/LGV_Est" title="LGV Est">LGV Est</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Fr%C3%A9jus_Rail_Tunnel" title="Fréjus Rail Tunnel">Fréjus Rail Tunnel</a>, the <a href="/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge" title="Øresund Bridge">Öresund Bridge</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Brenner_Base_Tunnel" title="Brenner Base Tunnel">Brenner Base Tunnel</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Messina_Bridge" title="Strait of Messina Bridge">Strait of Messina Bridge</a>. In 2010 the estimated network covers: 75,200 kilometres (46,700&#160;mi) of roads; 78,000 kilometres (48,000&#160;mi) of railways; 330 airports; 270 maritime harbours; and 210 internal harbours.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Europe" title="Rail transport in Europe">Rail transport in Europe</a> is being synchronised with the <a href="/wiki/European_Rail_Traffic_Management_System" title="European Rail Traffic Management System">European Rail Traffic Management System</a> (ERTMS), an initiative to greatly enhance safety, increase efficiency of trains and enhance cross-border interoperability of rail transport in Europe by replacing signalling equipment with digitised mostly wireless versions and by creating a single Europe-wide standard for train control and command systems.
</p><p>The developing European transport policies will increase the pressure on the environment in many regions by the increased transport network. In the pre-2004 EU members, the major problem in transport deals with congestion and pollution. After the recent enlargement, the new states that joined since 2004 added the problem of solving accessibility to the transport agenda.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Highways_in_Poland" title="Highways in Poland">Polish road network</a> was upgraded such as the <a href="/wiki/A4_autostrada_(Poland)" title="A4 autostrada (Poland)">A4 autostrada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Galileo_(satellite_navigation)" title="Galileo (satellite navigation)">Galileo positioning system</a> is another EU infrastructure project. Galileo is a proposed <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">Satellite navigation</a> system, to be built by the EU and launched by the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> (ESA). The Galileo project was launched partly to reduce the EU's dependency on the US-operated <a href="/wiki/Global_Positioning_System" title="Global Positioning System">Global Positioning System</a>, but also to give more complete global coverage and allow for greater accuracy, given the aged nature of the GPS system.<sup id="cite_ref-Barrot_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barrot-280">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 162px"><div style="width: 162px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 160px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg/240px-%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg/360px-%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg/480px-%C3%98resund_Bridge_from_the_air_in_September_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000" /></a></div></div>

</p>
			</div>

		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 186px"><div style="width: 186px">

</p>
