<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg/220px-RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg/330px-RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg/440px-RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RO_BZ_Pietroasele_vineyard.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vineyards in <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>; EU farms are supported by the <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/Budget_of_the_European_Union" title="Budget of the European Union">budgetary</a> expenditure.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a> (CAP) is one of the long lasting policies of the European Community.<sup id="cite_ref-stead_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stead-281">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> The policy has the objectives of increasing agricultural production, providing certainty in food supplies, ensuring a high quality of life for farmers, stabilising markets, and ensuring reasonable prices for consumers.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;ad&#93;</a></sup> It was, until recently, operated by a system of subsidies and market intervention. Until the 1990s, the policy accounted for over 60% of the then <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Community</a>'s annual budget, and as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Union&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> accounts for around 34%.<sup id="cite_ref-EU_CAP_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU_CAP-283">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The policy's <a href="/wiki/Incomes_policy" title="Incomes policy">price controls</a> and market interventions led to considerable <a href="/wiki/Overproduction" title="Overproduction">overproduction</a>. These were <a href="/wiki/Buffer_stock_scheme" title="Buffer stock scheme">intervention stores</a> of products bought up by the Community to maintain minimum price levels. To dispose of surplus stores, they were often sold on the world market at prices considerably below Community guaranteed prices, or farmers were offered subsidies (amounting to the difference between the Community and world prices) to export their products outside the Community. This system has been criticised for under-cutting farmers outside Europe, especially those in the <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">developing world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_CAP_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_CAP-284">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> Supporters of CAP argue that the economic support which it gives to farmers provides them with a reasonable standard of living.<sup id="cite_ref-Guardian_CAP_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian_CAP-284">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the beginning of the 1990s, the CAP has been subject to a series of reforms. Initially, these reforms included the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Set-aside" title="Set-aside">set-aside</a> in 1988, where a proportion of farm land was deliberately withdrawn from production, milk quotas and, more recently, the 'de-coupling' (or disassociation) of the money farmers receive from the EU and the amount they produce (by the Fischler reforms in 2004). Agriculture expenditure will move away from subsidy payments linked to specific produce, toward direct payments based on farm size. This is intended to allow the market to dictate production levels.<sup id="cite_ref-stead_281-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stead-281">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> One of these reforms entailed the modification of the EU's sugar regime, which previously divided the sugar market between member states and certain African-Caribbean nations with a privileged relationship with the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-EC_CAP_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EC_CAP-285">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Competition">Competition</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Union_competition_law" title="European Union competition law">European Union competition law</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Competition" title="European Commissioner for Competition">European Commissioner for Competition</a></div>
<p>The EU operates a <a href="/wiki/European_Union_competition_law" title="European Union competition law">competition policy</a> intended to ensure undistorted competition within the single market.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;ae&#93;</a></sup> The Commission as the competition regulator for the single market is responsible for antitrust issues, approving <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers</a>, breaking up cartels, working for <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalism" title="Economic liberalism">economic liberalisation</a> and preventing <a href="/wiki/Subsidy" title="Subsidy">state aid</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (January 2017)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_Competition" title="European Commissioner for Competition">Competition Commissioner</a>, currently <a href="/wiki/Margrethe_Vestager" title="Margrethe Vestager">Margrethe Vestager</a>, is one of the most powerful positions in the Commission, notable for the ability to affect the commercial interests of trans-national corporations.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (January 2017)">failed verification</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> For example, in 2001 the Commission for the first time prevented a merger between two companies based in the United States (<a href="/wiki/General_Electric" title="General Electric">GE</a> and <a href="/wiki/Honeywell" title="Honeywell">Honeywell</a>) which had already been approved by their national authority.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> Another high-profile case <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Microsoft_competition_case" class="mw-redirect" title="European Union Microsoft competition case">against Microsoft</a>, resulted in the Commission fining <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> over €777&#160;million following nine years of legal action.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_policy">Social policy</span></h2>
<p>The EU has long sought to mitigate the effects of free markets by protecting workers rights and preventing social and environmental dumping. To this end it has adopted laws establishing minimum employment and environmental standards. These included the <a href="/wiki/Working_Time_Directive" class="mw-redirect" title="Working Time Directive">Working Time Directive</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Impact_Assessment_Directive_2011" title="Environmental Impact Assessment Directive 2011">Environmental Impact Assessment Directive</a>. The EU has also sought to coordinate the social security and health systems of member states to facilitate individuals exercising free movement rights and to ensure they maintain their ability to access social security and health services in other member states.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/European_Commissioner_for_the_Environment" title="European Commissioner for the Environment">European Commissioner for the Environment</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Climate_Change_Programme" title="European Climate Change Programme">European Climate Change Programme</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Environment_Agency,_Copenhagen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/200px-European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/300px-European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/400px-European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2250" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Environment_Agency,_Copenhagen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/European_Environment_Agency" title="European Environment Agency">European Environment Agency</a> in <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen" title="Copenhagen">Copenhagen</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1957, when the EEC was founded, it had no environmental policy.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> Over the past 50 years, an increasingly dense network of legislation has been created, extending to all areas of environmental protection, including air pollution, water quality, waste management, nature conservation, and the control of chemicals, industrial hazards, and biotechnology.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_European_Environmental_Policy" title="Institute for European Environmental Policy">Institute for European Environmental Policy</a>, environmental law comprises over 500 Directives, Regulations and Decisions, making environmental policy a core area of European politics.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Environmental_Policy_2012_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Environmental_Policy_2012-293">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>European policy-makers originally increased the EU's capacity to act on environmental issues by defining it as a trade problem.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Trade_barrier" title="Trade barrier">Trade barriers</a> and competitive distortions in the Common Market could emerge due to the different environmental standards in each member state.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> In subsequent years, the environment became a formal policy area, with its own policy actors, principles and procedures. The legal basis for EU environmental policy was established with the introduction of the Single European Act in 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Environmental_Policy_2012_293-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Environmental_Policy_2012-293">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg/200px-European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="141" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg/300px-European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg/400px-European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="361" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:European_Union_biogeography_countries.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">Biogeographic regions</a> of the continental European Union, according to the <a href="/wiki/European_Environment_Agency" title="European Environment Agency">European Environmental Agency</a></div></div></div>
<p>Initially, EU environmental policy focused on Europe. More recently, the EU has demonstrated leadership in global environmental governance, e.g. the role of the EU in securing the ratification and coming into force of the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto Protocol</a> despite opposition from the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>. This international dimension is reflected in the EU's Sixth Environmental Action Programme,<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> which recognises that its objectives can only be achieved if key international agreements are actively supported and properly implemented both at EU level and worldwide. The Lisbon Treaty further strengthened the leadership ambitions.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> EU law has played a significant role in improving habitat and species protection in Europe, as well as contributing to improvements in air and water quality and waste management.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Environmental_Policy_2012_293-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Environmental_Policy_2012-293">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mitigating <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> is one of the top priorities of EU environmental policy. In 2007, member states agreed that, in the future, 20% of the energy used across the EU must be <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable</a>, and carbon dioxide emissions have to be lower in 2020 by at least 20% compared to 1990 levels.<sup id="cite_ref-EUO_energy_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUO_energy-298">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> The EU has adopted an <a href="/wiki/Emissions_trading" title="Emissions trading">emissions trading system</a> to incorporate <a href="/wiki/Carbon_emissions" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon emissions">carbon emissions</a> into the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Green_Capital" class="mw-redirect" title="European Green Capital">European Green Capital</a> is an annual award given to cities that focuses on the environment, energy efficiency, and quality of life in urban areas to create <a href="/wiki/Smart_city" title="Smart city">smart city</a>.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Elections_to_the_European_Parliament" title="Elections to the European Parliament">Elections to the European Parliament</a> in 2019, the green parties increased their power, possibly because of the rise of post materialist values.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Proposals to reach a zero carbon economy in the European Union by 2050 were suggested in 2018 - 2019. Almost all member states supported that goal at an EU summit in June 2019. The <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> disagreed.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_science">Education and science</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Educational_policies_and_initiatives_of_the_European_Union" title="Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union">Educational policies and initiatives of the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Holbein-erasmus.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Holbein-erasmus.jpg/170px-Holbein-erasmus.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="241" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Holbein-erasmus.jpg/255px-Holbein-erasmus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Holbein-erasmus.jpg/340px-Holbein-erasmus.jpg 2x" data-file-width="809" data-file-height="1145" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Holbein-erasmus.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Erasmus" title="Erasmus">Erasmus of Rotterdam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">Renaissance humanist</a> after whom the <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Programme" title="Erasmus Programme">Erasmus Programme</a> is named</div></div></div>
<p>Basic education is an area where the EU's role is limited to supporting national governments. In higher education, the policy was developed in the 1980s in programmes supporting exchanges and mobility. The most visible of these has been the <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Programme" title="Erasmus Programme">Erasmus Programme</a>, a university exchange programme which began in 1987. In its first 20&#160;years, it supported international exchange opportunities for well over 1.5&#160;million university and college students and became a symbol of European student life.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There are similar programmes for school pupils and teachers, for trainees in <a href="/wiki/Vocational_education" title="Vocational education">vocational education and training</a>, and for adult learners in the <a href="/wiki/Lifelong_Learning_Programme_2007%E2%80%932013" title="Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2013">Lifelong Learning Programme 2007–2013</a>. These programmes are designed to encourage a wider knowledge of other countries and to spread good practices in the education and training fields across the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> Through its support of the <a href="/wiki/Bologna_Process" title="Bologna Process">Bologna Process</a>, the EU is supporting comparable standards and compatible degrees across Europe.
</p><p>Scientific development is facilitated through the EU's <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">Framework Programmes</a>, the first of which started in 1984. The aims of EU policy in this area are to co-ordinate and stimulate research. The independent <a href="/wiki/European_Research_Council" title="European Research Council">European Research Council</a> allocates EU funds to European or national research projects.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> EU <a href="/wiki/Framework_Programmes_for_Research_and_Technological_Development" title="Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development">research and technological framework programmes</a> deal in a number of areas, for example energy where the aim is to develop a diverse mix of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewable energy</a> to help the environment and to reduce dependence on imported fuels.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Europe" title="Healthcare in Europe">Healthcare in Europe</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EHIC_Slovenia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/EHIC_Slovenia.jpg/220px-EHIC_Slovenia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/EHIC_Slovenia.jpg/330px-EHIC_Slovenia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/EHIC_Slovenia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="414" data-file-height="269" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EHIC_Slovenia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/European_Health_Insurance_Card" title="European Health Insurance Card">European Health Insurance Card</a><br />(Slovenian version pictured)</div></div></div>
<p>Although the EU has no major competences in the field of health care, Article 35 of the <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights_of_the_European_Union" title="Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union">Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union</a> affirms that "A high level of human health protection shall be ensured in the definition and implementation of all Union policies and activities". The <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_Health_and_Consumers_(European_Commission)" class="mw-redirect" title="Directorate-General for Health and Consumers (European Commission)">Directorate-General for Health and Consumers</a> seeks to align national laws on the protection of people's health, on the consumers' rights, on the safety of food and other products.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>All EU and many other European countries offer their citizens a free <a href="/wiki/European_Health_Insurance_Card" title="European Health Insurance Card">European Health Insurance Card</a> which, on a reciprocal basis, provides insurance for emergency medical treatment insurance when visiting other participating European countries.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> A directive on cross-border healthcare aims at promoting co-operation on health care between member states and facilitating access to safe and high-quality cross-border healthcare for European patients.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">Culture of Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">Western culture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_policies_of_the_European_Union" title="Cultural policies of the European Union">Cultural policies of the European Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_(pixinn.net).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg/220px-View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg/330px-View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg/440px-View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_%28pixinn.net%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1920" data-file-height="1156" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:View_of_the_Acropolis_Athens_2_(pixinn.net).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture" title="European Capital of Culture">European Capital of Culture</a> programme was launched in the summer of 1985 with <a href="/wiki/Athens" title="Athens">Athens</a> being the first title-holder</div></div></div>
<p>Cultural co-operation between member states has been a concern of the EU since its inclusion as a community competency in the Maastricht Treaty.<sup id="cite_ref-Bozoki_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bozoki-314">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> Actions taken in the cultural area by the EU include the <a href="/wiki/Culture_2000" title="Culture 2000">Culture 2000</a> seven-year programme,<sup id="cite_ref-Bozoki_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bozoki-314">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/European_Cultural_Month" title="European Cultural Month">European Cultural Month</a> event,<sup id="cite_ref-Culture_Month_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Culture_Month-315">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> and orchestras such as the <a href="/wiki/European_Union_Youth_Orchestra" title="European Union Youth Orchestra">European Union Youth Orchestra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture" title="European Capital of Culture">European Capital of Culture</a> programme selects one or more cities in every year to assist the <a href="/wiki/Sociocultural_evolution" title="Sociocultural evolution">cultural development</a> of that city.<sup id="cite_ref-Capital_Culture_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Capital_Culture-317">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_policies_of_the_European_Union" title="Sport policies of the European Union">Sport policies of the European Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_(2016).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_%282016%29.jpg/220px-Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_%282016%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_%282016%29.jpg/330px-Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_%282016%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_%282016%29.jpg/440px-Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_%282016%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3672" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Estadio_Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_(2016).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Football is one of the most popular sports in the European Union. (<a href="/wiki/Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_Stadium" title="Santiago Bernabéu Stadium">Santiago Bernabéu Stadium</a> in Madrid)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a> is by far the most popular sport in the European Union by the number of registered players. The other sports with the most participants in clubs are tennis, basketball, swimming, athletics, golf, gymnastics, equestrian sports, handball, volleyball and sailing.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Sport is mainly the responsibility of the member states or other international organisations, rather than of the EU. However, there are some EU policies that have affected sport, such as the free movement of workers, which was at the core of the <a href="/wiki/Bosman_ruling" title="Bosman ruling">Bosman ruling</a> that prohibited national football leagues from imposing quotas on foreign players with European citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_Boseman_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Boseman-319">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> requires any application of economic rules to take into account the specific nature of sport and its structures based on voluntary activity.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> This followed lobbying by governing organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> and <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a>, due to objections over the application of free market principles to sport, which led to an increasing gap between rich and poor clubs.<sup id="cite_ref-IHT_RT_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IHT_RT-321">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> The EU does fund a programme for Israeli, Jordanian, Irish, and British football coaches, as part of the Football 4 Peace project.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg/170px-Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="248" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg/255px-Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg/340px-Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2443" data-file-height="3564" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Aachen_Domschatz_Bueste1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bust_of_Charlemagne" title="Bust of Charlemagne">Bust of Charlemagne</a> with the German <i><a href="/wiki/Reichsadler" title="Reichsadler">Reichsadler</a></i> embossed on the metal and the French <a href="/wiki/Fleur-de-lis" title="Fleur-de-lis">fleur-de-lis</a> embroidered on the fabric. <a href="/wiki/Aachen_Cathedral_Treasury" title="Aachen Cathedral Treasury">Aachen Cathedral Treasury</a></div></div></div>
<p>The flag used is the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Europe" title="Flag of Europe">Flag of Europe</a>, which consists of a <a href="/wiki/Circle_of_stars" title="Circle of stars">circle of</a> 12 golden stars on a blue background. Originally designed in 1955 for the Council of Europe, the flag was adopted by the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a>, the predecessors of the present Union, in 1986. The Council of Europe gave the flag a symbolic description in the following terms,<sup id="cite_ref-36th_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36th-323">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> though the official symbolic description adopted by the EU omits the reference to the "Western world":<sup id="cite_ref-1996guide_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1996guide-324">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Against the blue sky of the Western world, the stars symbolise the peoples of Europe in a form of a circle, the sign of union. The number of stars is invariably <a href="/wiki/12_(number)#Religion" title="12 (number)">twelve</a>, the figure twelve being the symbol of perfection and entirety.</p><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite>Council of Europe. Paris, 7–9 December 1955.</cite></div>
</blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Abduction_of_Europa,_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/The_Abduction_of_Europa%2C_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg/220px-The_Abduction_of_Europa%2C_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/The_Abduction_of_Europa%2C_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg/330px-The_Abduction_of_Europa%2C_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/The_Abduction_of_Europa%2C_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg/440px-The_Abduction_of_Europa%2C_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3204" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Abduction_of_Europa,_Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Europa_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Europa (mythology)">Europa</a> and the bull, depicted by <a href="/wiki/Jean-Fran%C3%A7ois_de_Troy" class="mw-redirect" title="Jean-François de Troy">Jean-François de Troy</a> (1716)</div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Motto_of_the_European_Union" title="Motto of the European Union">United in Diversity</a></i> was adopted as the motto of the Union in the year 2000, having been selected from <a href="/wiki/A_motto_for_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="A motto for Europe">proposals</a> submitted by school pupils.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESimons2002110_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESimons2002110-325">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> Since 1985, the <a href="/wiki/Flag_day" class="mw-redirect" title="Flag day">flag day</a> of the Union has been <a href="/wiki/Europe_Day" title="Europe Day">Europe Day</a>, on 9 May (the date of the 1950 <a href="/wiki/Schuman_declaration" class="mw-redirect" title="Schuman declaration">Schuman declaration</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Anthem_of_Europe" title="Anthem of Europe">anthem of the Union</a> is an instrumental version of the prelude to the <i><a href="/wiki/Ode_to_Joy" title="Ode to Joy">Ode to Joy</a></i>, the 4th movement of <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven" title="Ludwig van Beethoven">Ludwig van Beethoven</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Symphony_No._9_(Beethoven)" title="Symphony No. 9 (Beethoven)">ninth symphony</a>. The anthem was adopted by European Community leaders in 1985 and has since been played on official occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup>
Besides naming the continent, the <a href="/wiki/Greek_mythology" title="Greek mythology">Greek mythological</a> figure of <a href="/wiki/Europa_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Europa (mythology)">Europa</a> has frequently been employed as a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">personification</a> of Europe. Known from the myth in which <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> seduces her in the guise of a white bull, Europa has also been referred to in relation to the present Union. Statues of Europa and the bull decorate several of the Union's institutions and a portrait of her is seen on the 2013 series of <a href="/wiki/Euro_banknotes" title="Euro banknotes">Euro banknotes</a>. The bull is, for its part, depicted on all residence permit cards.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDemey2007387_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDemey2007387-327">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charles the Great</a>, also known as Charlemagne (<a href="/wiki/Latin_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">Carolus Magnus</i>) and later recognised as <i>Pater Europae</i> ("Father of Europe"),<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-328">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup> has a symbolic relevance to Europe. The Commission has named <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne_building" title="Charlemagne building">one of its central buildings</a> in Brussels after Charlemagne and the city of <a href="/wiki/Aachen" title="Aachen">Aachen</a> has since 1949 awarded the <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne_Prize" title="Charlemagne Prize">Charlemagne Prize</a> to champions of European unification.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> Since 2008, the organisers of this prize, in conjunction with the European Parliament, have awarded the <a href="/wiki/European_Charlemagne_Youth_Prize" title="European Charlemagne Youth Prize">Charlemagne Youth Prize</a> in recognition of similar efforts by young people.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_the_European_Union" title="Media freedom in the European Union">Media freedom in the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Broadcasting_Union" title="European Broadcasting Union">European Broadcasting Union</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg/220px-Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg/330px-Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg/440px-Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1366" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Si%C3%A8ge_d%27Euronews.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Euronews" title="Euronews">Euronews</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Lyon" title="Lyon">Lyon</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Media_freedom" class="mw-redirect" title="Media freedom">Media freedom</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_rights" title="Fundamental rights">fundamental right</a> that applies to all <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member states</a> of the European Union and its <a href="/wiki/EU_citizens" class="mw-redirect" title="EU citizens">citizens</a>, as defined in the <a href="/wiki/EU_Charter_of_Fundamental_Rights" class="mw-redirect" title="EU Charter of Fundamental Rights">EU Charter of Fundamental Rights</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-eprs_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eprs-333">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>1</span></sup> Within the <a href="/wiki/EU_enlargement" class="mw-redirect" title="EU enlargement">EU enlargement</a> process, guaranteeing media freedom is named a "key indicator of a country's readiness to become part of the EU".<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The vast majority of media in the European Union are national-oriented. However, some EU-wide media focusing on European affairs have emerged since the early 1990s, such as <a href="/wiki/Euronews" title="Euronews">Euronews</a>, <a href="/wiki/EUobserver" title="EUobserver">EUobserver</a>, <a href="/wiki/EURACTIV" title="EURACTIV">EURACTIV</a> or <a href="/wiki/Politico_Europe" title="Politico Europe">Politico Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arte" title="Arte">ARTE</a> is a public Franco-German TV network that promotes programming in the areas of culture and the arts. 80% of its programming are provided in equal proportion by the two member companies, while the remainder is being provided by the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Interest_Grouping" class="mw-redirect" title="European Economic Interest Grouping">European Economic Interest Grouping</a> <i>ARTE GEIE</i> and the channel's European partners.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/MEDIA_Programme" class="mw-redirect" title="MEDIA Programme">MEDIA Programme</a> of the European Union intends to support the European popular film and audiovisual industries since 1991. It provides support for the development, promotion and distribution of European works within Europe and beyond.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The 24 languages are equally official and accepted as working languages. However, only three of them – English, French and German – have the higher status of <i>procedural languages</i> and are used in the day-to-day workings of the European institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup></span>

<li id="cite_note-art249-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-art249_176-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-art249_176-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">See Article 288 (ex Article 249 TEC) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, on <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2010:083:0047:0200:EN:PDF">eur-lex.europa.eu</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-Direct_Effect-177"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Direct_Effect_177-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the principle of Direct Effect first invoked in the Court of Justice's decision in <cite><i><a href="/wiki/Van_Gend_en_Loos_v_Nederlandse_Administratie_der_Belastingen" title="Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen">Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen</a></i></cite>,&#32;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61962J0026:EN:NOT">&#32;Eur-Lex</a>&#32;(European Court of Justice&#32;1963).  See: Craig and de Búrca, ch. 5.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Supremacy-179"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Supremacy_179-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to the principle of <a href="/wiki/Law_of_the_European_Union#Supremacy" class="mw-redirect" title="Law of the European Union">Supremacy</a> as established by the ECJ in Case 6/64, <i>Falminio Costa v. ENEL</i> [1964] ECR 585. See Craig and de Búrca, ch. 7. See also: <a href="/wiki/Factortame_litigation" class="mw-redirect" title="Factortame litigation">Factortame litigation</a>: <i>Factortame Ltd. v. Secretary of State for Transport (No. 2) [1991] 1 AC 603</i>, <i>Solange II</i> (<i>Re Wuensche Handelsgesellschaft</i>, BVerfG decision of 22 October 1986 [1987] 3 CMLR 225,265) and <i>Frontini v. Ministero delle Finanze</i> [1974] 2 CMLR 372; <i>Raoul George Nicolo</i> [1990] 1 CMLR 173.</span>
</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">

<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Current Article 1 of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Maastricht" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Maastricht">Treaty on European Union</a> reads: "The Union shall be founded on the present Treaty and on the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>. Those <a href="/wiki/Treaties_of_the_EU" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaties of the EU">two Treaties</a> shall have the same legal value. The Union shall replace and succeed the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" class="mw-redirect" title="European Community">European Community</a>".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">europarltv, official webtv of the European Parliament, is also available in all EU languages <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.europarltv.europa.eu/en/home.aspx">[1]</a></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Jewish population figures may be unreliable. <cite class="citation web">Sergio DellaPergola. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20041222130930/http://www.jafi.org.il/education/100/concepts/demography/demjpop.html">"World Jewish Population (2002)"</a>. <i>American Jewish Year Book</i>. The Jewish Agency for Israel. </li>
<li id="cite_note-144"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-144">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to P.C. Schmitter, <b>Comparative Politics: Its Past, Present and Future</b> (2016), 1 Chinese Political Science Review, 397, at 410, "European Union is the most complex polity in the world".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-145">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">These legislative instruments are dealt with in more detail <a href="#Acts">below</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-146">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Kiljunen, Kimmo (2004). The European Constitution in the Making. Centre for European Policy Studies. pp. 21–26. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-92-9079-493-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-92-9079-493-6">978-92-9079-493-6</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-147"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-147">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Burgess, Michael (2000). Federalism and European union: The building of Europe, 1950–2000. Routledge. p. 49. <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-415-22647-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-415-22647-3">0-415-22647-3</a>. "Our theoretical analysis suggests that the EC/EU is neither a federation nor a confederation in the classical sense. But it does claim that the European political and economic elites have shaped and moulded the EC/EU into a new form of international organization, namely, a species of "new" confederation."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-220"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-220">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation conference">Laursen, Finn (29 May – 1 June 1997). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://aei.pitt.edu/2657/">"The EU 'neutrals,' the CFSP and defence policy"</a>. <i>Biennial Conference of the European Union Studies Association</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 July</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=conference&amp;rft.atitle=The+EU+%27neutrals%2C%27+the+CFSP+and+defence+policy&amp;rft.btitle=Biennial+Conference+of+the+European+Union+Studies+Association&amp;rft.place=Seattle%2C+WA&amp;rft.pages=27&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Pittsburgh&amp;rft.date=1997-05-29%2F1997-06-01&amp;rft.aulast=Laursen&amp;rft.aufirst=Finn&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Faei.pitt.edu%2F2657%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-221">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.weu.int/Declaration_E.pdf">Statement of the Presidency of the Permanent Council of the WEU</a> – on behalf of the High Contracting Parties to the Modified Brussels Treaty – Belgium, France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain and the United Kingdom – Western European Union 31 March 2010.</span>

<li id="cite_note-222"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-222">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100328072123/http://milexdata.sipri.org/">"The SIPRI Military Expenditure Database"</a>. Milexdata.sipri.org. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://milexdata.sipri.org/">the original</a> on 28 March 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 June</span> 2013</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+SIPRI+Military+Expenditure+Database&amp;rft.pub=Milexdata.sipri.org&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmilexdata.sipri.org%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-223">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&amp;objectid=10685127">"Britain and France to work together"</a> by Catherine Field. 4 November 2010. nzherald.co.nz. According to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Britain spent more than US$69 billion on defence last year, placing it third in the world after the United States and China, while France spent US$67.31 billion, the fourth largest. Together, Britain and France account for 45 per cent of Europe's defence budget, 50 per cent of its military capacity and 70 per cent of all spending in military research and development. Copyright 2010, APN Holdings NZ Limited.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-241"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-241">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation magazine">D.C. Dispatch (1 February 2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080828194231/http://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200502u/nj_rauch_2005-02-01">"Europe Is the Next Rival Superpower. <li id="cite_note-EurostatEnergy-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-EurostatEnergy_270-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-EurostatEnergy_270-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation pressrelease"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080923204027/http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/pls/portal/docs/PAGE/PGP_PRD_CAT_PREREL/PGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008/PGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008_MONTH_07/8-10072008-EN-AP.PDF">"Energy consumption and production: EU27 energy dependence rate at 54% in 2006: Energy consumption stable"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> (Press release). Eurostat. 10 July 2008. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/pls/portal/docs/PAGE/PGP_PRD_CAT_PREREL/PGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008/PGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008_MONTH_07/8-10072008-EN-AP.PDF">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 23 September 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 September</span> 2008</span>. <q><br /> In the EU27, gross inland energy consumption was 1 825&#160;million tonnes of oil equivalent (toe) in 2006, stable compared with 2005, while energy production decreased by 2.3% to 871 mn toe&#160;...<br /> Gross inland consumption is defined as primary production plus imports, recovered products and stock change, less exports and fuel supply to maritime bunkers (for seagoing ships of all flags)&#160;... <br /> A tonne of oil equivalent (toe) is a standardised unit defined on the basis of one tonne of oil having a net calorific value of 41.868 Gigajoules.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Energy+consumption+and+production%3A+EU27+energy+dependence+rate+at+54%25+in+2006%3A+Energy+consumption+stable&amp;rft.pub=Eurostat&amp;rft.date=2008-07-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fepp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu%2Fpls%2Fportal%2Fdocs%2FPAGE%2FPGP_PRD_CAT_PREREL%2FPGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008%2FPGE_CAT_PREREL_YEAR_2008_MONTH_07%2F8-10072008-EN-AP.PDF&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Euratom2007-271"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Euratom2007_271-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Euratom2007_271-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ec.europa.eu/euratom/ar/last.pdf">"EU supply and demand for nuclear fuels"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Euratom Supply Agency – Annual Report 2007</i>. Luxembourg: Office for Official Publications of the European Communities. 2008. p.&#160;22. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-92-79-09437-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-92-79-09437-8"><bdi>978-92-79-09437-8</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 March</span> 2009</span>. <q>European uranium mining supplied just below 3% of the total EU needs, coming from the Czech Republic and Romania (a total of 526 tU).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=EU+supply+and+demand+for+nuclear+fuels&amp;rft.btitle=Euratom+Supply+Agency+%E2%80%93+Annual+Report+2007&amp;rft.place=Luxembourg&amp;rft.pages=22&amp;rft.pub=Office+for+Official+Publications+of+the+European+Communities&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-92-79-09437-8&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fec.europa.eu%2Feuratom%2Far%2Flast.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> <br />
 Nuclear energy and renewable energy are treated differently from oil, gas, and coal in this respect.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-EU_CAP-283"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-EU_CAP_283-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111129003403/http://europa.eu/pol/agr/index_en.htm">"Agriculture: Meeting the needs of farmers and consumers"</a>. <i>Europa: Gateway to the European Union</i>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">4 November</span> 2011</span>. <q>the common agricultural policy is the most integrated of all EU policies and consequently takes a large share of the EU budget. Nevertheless, its portion of the EU budget has dropped from a peak of nearly 70% in the 1970s to 34% over the 2007–2013 period.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Europa%3A+Gateway+to+the+European+Union&amp;rft.atitle=Agriculture%3A+Meeting+the+needs+of+farmers+and+consumers&amp;rft.date=2011-08-26&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feuropa.eu%2Fpol%2Fagr%2Findex_en.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-IHT_RT-321"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-IHT_RT_321-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20081201201945/http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/10/19/sports/EU-SPT-OLY-EU-Treaty.php">"IOC, FIFA presidents welcomes new EU treaty, call it breakthrough to give sports more power"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/International_Herald_Tribune" class="mw-redirect" title="International Herald Tribune">International Herald Tribune</a></i>. 19 October 2007. <li id="cite_note-36th-323"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36th_323-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090528195931/http://www.coe.int/t/dgal/dit/ilcd/Fonds/Themes/Flags/Res%2855%2932_en.pdf"><i>Thirty-sixth meeting of the ministers' deputies: resolution (55) 32</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>, Council of Europe, 9 December 1955, archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.coe.int/t/dgal/dit/ilcd/fonds/themes/flags/Res(55)32_en.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 28 May 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 February</span> 2008</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Thirty-sixth+meeting+of+the+ministers%27+deputies%3A+resolution+%2855%29+32&amp;rft.pub=Council+of+Europe&amp;rft.date=1955-12-09&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.coe.int%2Ft%2Fdgal%2Fdit%2Filcd%2Ffonds%2Fthemes%2Fflags%2FRes%2855%2932_en.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-1996guide-324"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1996guide_324-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="languageicon">(in French)</span> <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cvce.eu/en/obj/guide_graphique_relatif_a_l_embleme_europeen_1996-fr-93eedaa0-b431-4ca8-ac7b-113ca01c0395.html">Guide graphique relatif à l'emblème européen</a></i> (1996), p. 3: <i>Description symbolique: Sur le fond bleu du ciel, les étoiles figurant les peuples d'Europe forment un cercle en signe d'union. Elles sont au nombre invariable de douze, symbole de la perfection et de la plénitude</i>...<i>Description héraldique: Sur fond azur, un cercle composé de douze étoiles d'or à cinq rais, dont les pointes ne se touchent pas</i>. c.f. <cite class="citation"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060622134708/http://europa.eu/abc/symbols/emblem/graphics1_en.htm#symbol"><i>Graphical specifications for the European Emblem</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Europa_(web_portal)" title="Europa (web portal)">European Commission</a>, archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://europa.eu/abc/symbols/emblem/graphics1_en.htm#symbol">the original</a> on 22 June 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">4 August</span> 2004</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Graphical+specifications+for+the+European+Emblem&amp;rft.pub=European+Commission&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Feuropa.eu%2Fabc%2Fsymbols%2Femblem%2Fgraphics1_en.htm%23symbol&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li><cite class="citation book">Le Gales, Patrick; King, Desmond (2017). <i>Reconfiguring European States in Crisis</i>. Corby: Oxford University Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-879337-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-879337-3"><bdi>978-0-19-879337-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Reconfiguring+European+States+in+Crisis&amp;rft.place=Corby&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-879337-3&amp;rft.aulast=Le+Gales&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrick&amp;rft.au=King%2C+Desmond&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></li>
<li>McAuley, James, "A More Perfect Union?" (review of <a href="/wiki/Luuk_van_Middelaar" title="Luuk van Middelaar">Luuk van Middelaar</a>, <i>Alarums and Excursions:  Improving Politics on the European Stage</i>, translated from the Dutch by Liz Waters, Agenda, 2019, 301 pp.; and Stéphanie Hennette, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Piketty" title="Thomas Piketty">Thomas Piketty</a>, Guillaume Sacriste, and Antoine Vauchez, <i>How to Democratize  Europe</i>, translated from the French by Paul Dermine, Marc LePain, and Patrick Camiller, Harvard University Press, 2019, 209 pp.), <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Review_of_Books" title="The New York Review of Books">The New York Review of Books</a></i>, vol. LXVI, no. 13 (15 August 2019), pp.&#160;46–48.  James McAuley writes:  "There was never a single moment that marked the definitive establishment of the European Union, which... has continued to define itself since <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.  [T]he major turning points have all been quiet steps on the way to further <a href="/wiki/Economic_integration" title="Economic integration">economic integration</a> while preserving <a href="/wiki/National_sovereignty" class="mw-redirect" title="National sovereignty">national sovereignty</a>.  Today there is only an incomplete <a href="/wiki/Monetary_union" class="mw-redirect" title="Monetary union">monetary union</a> without a real political contract to manage it...  [Nevertheless, the Union's] various peoples have grown remarkably closer...  The European Union now has open borders, a single market from Portugal to the Baltics, and more or less monthly meetings of member state leaders [the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a>].  What's more, those member states are now closer to each other than they are to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>...  [T]his transformation has occurred informally and organically...  [R]obust supranational politics are taking root in Europe...  <a href="/wiki/Luuk_van_Middelaar" title="Luuk van Middelaar">Luuk van Middelaar</a> writes:  '[W]hat unites us as Europeans on this continent is bigger and stronger than anything that divides us.'"  (pp.&#160;47–48.)</li>
<li><cite class="citation book">McCormick, John (2007). <i>The European Union: Politics and Policies</i> (5th ed.). Boulder, CO: <a href="/wiki/Westview_Press" title="Westview Press">Westview Press</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8133-4202-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8133-4202-3"><bdi>978-0-8133-4202-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+European+Union%3A+Politics+and+Policies&amp;rft.place=Boulder%2C+CO&amp;rft.edition=5th&amp;rft.pub=Westview+Press&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8133-4202-3&amp;rft.aulast=McCormick&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEuropean+Union" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Mount" title="Ferdinand Mount">Mount, Ferdinand</a>, "Why We Go to War", <i><a href="/wiki/London_Review_of_Books" title="London Review of Books">London Review of Books</a></i>, vol. 41, no. 11 (6 June 2019), pp.&#160;11–14.  "[H]istorians have tended to weave their narratives around [...] high-flown themes:  the struggle to maintain the <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_power_(international_relations)" title="Balance of power (international relations)">balance of power</a>, the struggles against <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">fascism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communism</a>, against the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> or <a href="/wiki/Militarism#Germany" title="Militarism">German militarism</a>.  In reality, most large <a href="/wiki/War" title="War">wars</a> have contained within them a violent and persistent economic conflict. [p. 12.]  Not for one second do [the <a href="/wiki/U.K." class="mw-redirect" title="U.K.">U.K.</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Brexit" title="Brexit">Brexiteers</a>] pause to think how hard-won [Europe's economic integration and peace, within the European Union, have] been.  They are the feckless children of seventy years of peace." [p.&#160;14.]</li>
<li><cite class="citation book">Pinder, John; Usherwood, Simon (2013). <i>The European Union: A Very Short Introduction</i> (3rd ed.). <li><a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">V4</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/West_Nordic_Council" title="West Nordic Council">West Nordic Council</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Topics</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Regional_integration" title="Regional integration">Regional integration</a></li>

<div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="Intellectual_property_laws_in_the_European_Union_(EU)" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="3"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Intellectual_property_laws_of_the_European_Union" title="Template:Intellectual property laws of the European Union"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; <li><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgrey">1967</span></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1968: <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Cassin" title="René Cassin">René Cassin</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1969: <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">International Labour Organization</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1970: <a href="/wiki/Norman_Borlaug" title="Norman Borlaug">Norman Borlaug</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1971: <a href="/wiki/Willy_Brandt" title="Willy Brandt">Willy Brandt</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgrey">1972</span></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1973: <i><a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BB%8D" title="Lê Đức Thọ">Lê Đức Thọ</a>&#160;(declined award)</i>&#160;/&#32;<a href="/wiki/Henry_Kissinger" title="Henry Kissinger">Henry Kissinger</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1974: <a href="/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_MacBride" title="Seán MacBride">Seán MacBride</a>&#160;/&#32;<a href="/wiki/Eisaku_Sat%C5%8D" title="Eisaku Satō">Eisaku Satō</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap">1975: <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Sakharov" title="Andrei Sakharov">Andrei Sakharov</a></span></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">1976–2000</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><span class="nowrap">1976: <a href="/wiki/Betty_Williams_(Nobel_laureate)" title="Betty Williams (Nobel laureate)">Betty Williams</a>&#160;/&#32;<a href="/wiki/Mairead_Maguire" title="Mairead Maguire">Mairead Corrigan</a></span></li>
